APPLICATION PURPOSE: THE GOAL IS THE IMPLEMENTATION OF PASSENGER SHELTERS AND BUS BOARDING AND ALIGHTING AREAS IN THE SERVICE REGION OF COMMUNITY CONNECTOR. THE CITY OF BANGOR COMMUNITY CONNECTOR BUS SERVICE IS IN CRITICAL NEED OF PASSENGER SHELTERS AND BUS STOPS. COMMUNITY CONNECTOR BUS SERVICE HAS BEEN A FLAG STOP TRANSIT SYSTEM SINCE THE BEGINNING OF TIME AND ITS THE ONLY SYSTEM LEFT IN THE STATE OF MAINE THAT ALLOWS FLAG BUS STOPS. THE TRANSIT SYSTEM HAS NO DESIGNED BUS STOPS THIS PROJECT WILL NEED TO START FROM THE GROUND UP. FIRST UP WITH BE THE DEVELOPMENT OF A BUS STOP DESIGN AND MANAGEMENT GUIDELINES.THE COMMUNITY CONNECTOR TRANSIT SYSTEM STILL HAS FLAG STOPS ALONG ALL 10 ROUTES AND IT IS IMPOSSIBLE TO MOVE TO ANY TYPE OF REAL TIME AVL OR ANY TYPE OF SMART TECHNOLOGY IF THERE ARE NO BUS STOPS. IMPLEMENTING PASSENGER SHELTERS AND BUS BOARDING ALONG OUR 29 SQUARE MILES SERVICE AREA WILL BE A GAME CHANGER. IN OUR LAST TRANSIT RIDER SURVEYS - RIDERS AND DRIVERS ALIKE ARE ASKING FOR THIS IMPROVEMENT. BUS STOPS HAS A MAJOR IMPACT ON TRANSIT PERFORMANCE. BUS STOPS ARE A KEY LINK IN THE JOURNEY OF A BUS RIDER. BUS STOPS PLAY A CRITICAL ROLE IN COMMUNICATING TO PASSENGERS AND TRANSIT OPERATORS ALIKE WHERE TO BOARD AND GET OFF THE BUSES. THIS IS WHY THIS PROJECT IS SO IMPORTANT AND VITAL TO OUR TRANSIT SYSTEM.; ACTIVITIES PERFORMED: THE GOAL OF THE AWARD IS TO DEVELOP A DESIGNED BUS STOP AND BUS SHELTER DESIGN AND MANAGEMENT GUIDELINES. THIS NEEDS TO BE APPROVED AND THEN THE GUIDELINES CAN BE USED TO SETUP THE INITIAL BUS STOPS AND SHELTERS FOR ALL THE ROUTES. PUBLIC MEETINGS DRIVER MEETINGS AND TONS OF OUT REACH WILL NEED TO HAD ALONG THE WAY. PUBLIC MEETINGS FOR CITIZEN AND FOR PASSENGERS ALIKE. THERE WILL NEED TO BE A LOT OF SITE WORK VISITS TO THE SITE OF THE BUS STOPS AND SHELTERS. MAPS WILL NEED TO BE MADE TASKS WILL NEED TO BE OUTLINED. RESEARCH WILL BE TO HAPPEN.AFTER ALL THAT THE BUS STOPS AND BUS SHELTERS WILL BE ON THE GROUND.; EXPECTED OUTCOMES: DEVELOPING DESIGNED BUS STOPS WILL BETTER CONNECT BANGORS TRANSIT SERVICE TO THE NEIGHBORHOODS AND COMMUNITIES SERVED BY THE COMMUNITY CONNECTOR. ESTABLISHING DEDICATED STOPS WILL MAKE THE RIDERS EXPERIENCE SAFER MORE CONVENIENT AND PREDICTABLE ESPECIALLY WHEN REAL TIME INFORMATION IS AVAILABLE. BY COMBINING TECHNOLOGY WITH BUS STOPS THE COMMUNITY CONNECTOR CAN ACHIEVE EFFICIENCIES WHILE ACCELERATING THE IMPROVEMENTS IN SERVICE. THE PROVISION OF BUS STOPS ACROSS THE COMMUNITY CONNECTOR NETWORK WILL BE CONSISTENT TO MAXIMIZE THE EFFECTIVENESS AND EFFICIENCY OF SERVICE AND TO PROVIDE CONVENIENT ACCESS TO A SIGNIFICANT PORTION OF THE REGIONS POPULATION. THE BUS STOP SITING WILL INVOLVE RIDERSHIP TRAVEL TIME CONNECTIVITY TRANSFER POINTS ACCESSIBILITY LAND USE SAFETY STREETSCAPES AND PUBLIC PARTICIPATION. OUR PLAN WOULD PROPOSE CRITERIA FOR PLACEMENT OF BUS STOPS SUGGESTIONS ON HOW THE ROADWAYS CAN BE CONFINED AND TREATED TO MAKE THE BUS STOPS SAFE FOR BOTH RIDERS AND MOTORIST. THE PLAN WOULD LAY OUT THE TYPES AND LEVELS OF AMENITIES HOW THE STOPS AND AMENITIES SHOULD BE MAINTAINED WHILE INCORPORATING THE TITLE VI AND ADA REQUIREMENTS. BETTER BUS STOPS MAKE BETTER CITIES. THE PROVISION OF BUS STOPS ACROSS THE COMMUNITY CONNECTOR NETWORK WILL BE CONSISTENT TO MAXIMIZE THE EFFECTIVENESS AND EFFICIENCY OF SERVICE AND TO PROVIDE CONVENIENT ACCESS TO A SIGNIFICANT PORTION OF THE REGIONS POPULATION. THE BUS STOP SITING WILL INVOLVE RIDERSHIP TRAVEL TIME CONNECTIVITY TRANSFER POINTS ACCESSIBILITY LAND USE SAFETY STREETSCAPES AND PUBLIC PARTICIPATION. OUR PLAN WOULD PROPOSE CRITERIA FOR PLACEMENT OF BUS STOPS SUGGESTIONS ON HOW THE ROADWAYS CAN BE CONFINED AND TREATED TO MAKE THE BUS STOPS SAFE FOR BOTH RIDERS AND MOTORIST. THE PLAN WOULD LAY OUT THE TYPES AND LEVELS OF AMENITIES HOW THE STOPS AND AMENITIES SHOULD BE MAINTAINED WHILE INCORPORATING THE TITLE VI AND ADA REQUIREMENTS. BETTER BUS STOPS MAKE BETTER CITIES. ; INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: OUR CURRENT PASSENGERS OUR FUTURE PASSENGERS AND CITIZENS IN OUR SERVICE AREA. THE COMMUNITY CONNECTOR TRANSIT SYSTEM WILL BE ABLE TO BE BE SEEN AND THE GUESS WORK ON WHERE TO CHECK THE BUS WILL BE ELIMINATED. CITIZENS IN ALL THE SERVICING TOWNS AND CITIES WILL KNOW WHERE TO STAND FOR THE BUS. IT WILL BRING THE BUS CLOSER TO EVERYONE AND IT WAS THERE ALL THE TIME.; SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NONE

APPLICATION PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO PROVIDE FY20 FY21 FY22 AND FY23 5339 FORMULA FUNDS AS CAPITAL TO PURCHASE TWO (2) THIRTY-FIVE (35) FOOT TRANSIT BUSES TO REPLACE TWO BUSES THAT WERE SUBJECT TO CATASTROPHIC LOSSES IN FY2022.; ACTIVITIES PERFORMED: THE TWO BUSES WILL REPLACE BUSES IN LATCS FLEET BOTH OF WHICH WERE TOTAL CATASTROPHIC LOSSES AND ARE PERMANENTLY OUT OF SERVICE.; EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THESE BUSES WILL RIGHT SIZE THE FLEET AND RETURN LATCS CITYLINK FLEET TO A STATE OF GOOD REPAIR.; INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: RESIDENTS AND RIDERS IN THE LEWISTON/AUBURN MAINE URBANIZED AREA; SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NONE

APPLICATION PURPOSE: THIS APPLICATION IS TO REQUEST FY22 SECTION 5339 FUNDS APPORTIONED TO MAINE IN THE AMOUNT OF $3040000 TO BE MATCHED BY $760000 IN STATE FUNDS. THESE ADDITIONAL FUNDS ARE NECESSARY TO COMPLETE PHASE 2 OF THE ACADIA GATEWAY CENTER PROJECT FUNDED MOST RECENTLY UNDER GRANT ME-2022-016 AND OTHERS. SEE LIST OF GRANT FUNDS BELOW IN EXECUTIVE SUMMARY.; ACTIVITIES PERFORMED: THE ACADIA GATEWAY CENTER IS A COMBINED INTERMODAL WELCOME CENTER AND BUS MAINTENANCE FACILITY IN TRENTON MAINE DESIGNED TO INTERCEPT DAY VISITORS TO ACADIA NATIONAL PARK AND OTHER DESTINATIONS ON MOUNT DESERT ISLAND AND TRANSFER THEM TO THE ISLAND EXPLORER BUS SYSTEM. PHASE 2 WILL ENTAIL FINAL DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION OF THE INTERMODAL FACILITY AND VISITOR WELCOME CENTER DELIVERING LONG-AWAITED PUBLIC BENEFITS INCLUDING SAFETY IMPROVEMENTS CONGESTION MITIGATION RESOURCE PROTECTION AND PRESERVATION OF THE VISITOR EXPERIENCE. COMPLETION OF THE INTERMODAL CENTER WILL FULFILL RECOMMENDATIONS OF BOTH THE FTA-LED NEPA REVIEW ISSUED IN 2006 AND THE NPS RECORD OF DECISION ON THE ACADIA NATIONAL PARK TRANSPORTATION PLAN ISSUED IN 2019. THE PLAN WAS APPROVED ON MAY 9 2019 CONFIRMING THAT CONSTRUCTION OF THE ACADIA GATEWAY CENTER INTERMODAL FACILITY IS A CRITICAL COMPONENT OF MANAGING TRAFFIC AND PROMOTING SAFETY WHILE PROTECTING NATURAL RESOURCES ROADWAY INFRASTRUCTURE AND VISITOR EXPERIENCE AT THE MOST POPULAR NATIONAL PARK IN THE EASTERN UNITED STATES.THIS GRANT SPECIFICALLY WILL FUND CERTAIN ASPECTS OF THE PROJECT SUCH AS PAVEMENT/ASPHALT ITEMS AND CLEARING/EARTHWORK. PHASE 1 OF THE PROJECT INCLUDING ALL-PHASE SITE PLANNING AND CONSTRUCTION OF THE ROAD BUS MAINTENANCE FACILITY AND PARK AND RIDE LOT WAS COMPLETED IN 2012.; EXPECTED OUTCOMES: REDUCED CONGESTION IN AND AROUND ACADIA NATIONAL PARK AND SURROUNDING COMMUNITIES ALONG WITH IMPROVED SAFETY CORRIDORS FOR THE ISLAND EXPLORER BUS SERVICE.; INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: RESIDENTS IN THE REGION VISITORS TO ACADIA NATIONAL PARK AND NEIGHBORING COMMUNITIES SUCH AS BAR HARBOR.; SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NA

APPLICATION PURPOSE: THIS PROJECT IS TO OBTAIN AND INSTALL 2 ON ROUTE PANTOGRAPH CHARGING STATIONS TO MAXIMIZE UTILITY OF THE ELECTRIC BUS VEHICLES THAT WERE RECENTLY PURCHASED.; ACTIVITIES PERFORMED: TWO PANTOGRAPH CHARGERS WILL BE INSTALLED AT THE SACO TRANSPORTATION CENTER.; EXPECTED OUTCOMES: WITHOUT ON-ROUTE CHARGING IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT THE ELECTRIC BUSES WILL ONLY BE ABLE TO COMPLETE A HALF DAY OF OPERATION BEFORE RETURNING TO THE MAINTENANCE CHARGERS. ON-ROUTE OVERHEAD CHARGERS WILL ALLOW THE ELECTRIC BUSES TO CHARGE AT THE SACO TRANSPORTATION CENTER AND WILL ALLOW FOR BUSES TO OPERATE FOR A FULL DAY.; INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THE RIDERS WILL BENEFIT BY ENJOYING TRANSPORTATION IN A NEW QUIET NON-POLLUTING OR GHG EMITTING BUS. THE COMMUNITY WILL ALSO BENEFIT BY HAVING ELECTRIC BUSES IN THE AREA INSTEAD OF DIESEL BUSES. THE NEIGHBORHOODS WILL EXPERIENCE LESS NOISE AND LESS EMISSIONS THAN THEY NORMALLY DO FROM THE DIESEL BUSES. CHARGING AT THE SACO TRANSPORTATION CENTER IS MORE EFFICIENT FOR BUS OPERATIONS THAN RETURNING TO THE BIDDEFORD GARAGE FOR CHARGING.; SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NONE.

APPLICATION PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THE AWARD IS TO PROVIDE FUNDING FOR THE PURCHASE OF FOUR (4) REPLACEMENT BUSES. BUSES BEING REPLACED INCLUDE THREE (3) 2016 MEDIUM DUTY GASOLINE POWERED CUTAWAY BUSES AND ONE (1) 2017 MEDIUM DUTY GASOLINE POWERED CUTAWAY BUS WHICH WILL HAVE AT THE TIME OF REPLACEMENT EXCEEDED THEIR USEFUL LIFE IN BOTH YEARS AND/OR MILEAGE.; ACTIVITIES PERFORMED: FOUR (4) BUSES WILL BE REPLACED. REPLACEMENT BUSES WILL BE 35-FOOT DIESEL BUSES MANUFACTURED BY NEW FLYER UNDER AN EXISTING COMPETITIVELY PROCURED FTA COMPLIANT CONTRACT.; EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THIS PROJECT WILL IMPROVE THE STATE OF GOOD REPAIR FOR TRANSIT ASSETS AT GPTD IMPROVE SERVICE RELIABILITY EXPAND PASSENGER CAPACITY AND IMPROVE FLEET INTEROPERABILITY.; INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: POPULATION AND TRANSIT RIDERS WITHIN GPTDS SERVICE AREA.; SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NONE.

THE CITY OF BANGOR COMMUNITY CONNECTOR REQUESTS $3076800 IN SECTION 5339 COMPETITIVE AND FORMULA FUNDING APPORTIONED TO THE MAINE STATEWIDE UZA. MATCHING FUNDS WILL BE SUPPORTED BY THE CITY OF BANGOR AND ITS MEMBER COMMUNITIES IN THE AMOUNT $769200 FOR TOTAL PROJECT COST OF $3846000. THE CITY OF BANGOR WAS SELECTED TO RECEIVE THIS FUNDING THROUGH THE FY19 5339(B) BUS AND BUS FACILITIES DISCRETIONARY PROGRAM ON NOVEMBER 20 2019. THE DISCRETIONARY PROJECT IDENTIFICATION NUMBER IS D2020-BUSC-043. THE FEDERAL REGISTER VOL. NO. (NOTICE OF AWARD IS ATTACHED). THE MAINEDOT ALSO SUPPORTED FUNDING THIS PROJECT BY TRANSFERRING FY20 SECTION 5339 NATIONAL DISTRIBUTION FUNDS (TRANSFER LETTER ATTACHED).THE PROJECT WILL BE SUPPORTED BY THE FOLLOWING FUNDING SOURCES:$1286000 IN FY19 SECTION 5339(B) DISCRETIONARY FUNDING$1790800 IN FY20 21 SECTION 5339 FORMULA FUNDINGON AUGUST 25 2020 THE MAINE HISTORICAL COMMISSION CONCURRED WITH THE FTAS FINDING OF NO ADVERSE EFFECT ON THIS PROJECT CONDITIONAL ON THE OPPORTUNITY TO REVIEW DESIGN PLANS AT THE 30% AND 90% STAGE. ON JANUARY 21 2021 THE MAINE HISTORICAL COMMISSION COMPLETED REVIEW OF 30% DESIGN PLANS AND DETERMINED THAT FURTHER REVIEW AT THE 90% STAGE WAS NO LONGER NECESSARY. PER THE FTAS LETTER TO THE CITY OF BANGOR ON JULY 10 2020 THIS PROJECT QUALIFIED FOR A CATEGORICAL EXCLUSION IN ACCORDANCE WITH 23 CFR 771.118(D)(8): MODERNIZATION OR MINOR EXPANSIONS OF TRANSIT STRUCTURES AND FACILITIES OUTSIDE EXISTING RIGHT-OF-WAY SUCH AS BRIDGES STATIONS OR RAIL YARDS.PURPOSE: THIS FUNDING WILL SUPPORT THE CONSTRUCTION OF NEW TRANSIT CENTER LOCATED AT PICKERING SQUARE (25 BROAD ST. ) IN THE HEART OF DOWNTOWN BANGOR MAINE. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE NEW MODERN TRANSIT CENTER WILL BE APPROXIMATELY A 2000 SQUARE FOOT FACILITY WITH AN ATTACHED BUS PLATFORM THAT CAN ACCOMMODATE UP TO 7 BUSES. THE NEW FACILITY WILL INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING AMENITIES WAITING AREA TICKET AREA SECURITY OFFICE AND BREAK ROOM FOR DRIVERS AND COMMUNITY CONNECTOR EMPLOYEES. THE NEW FACILITY WILL COMPLY WITH ALL ADA REQUIREMENTS AND IMPROVE THE OVERALL ACCESSIBILITY AND MOBILITY TO THE SERVICE AREA. EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE NEW TRANSIT CENTER WILL PROVIDE A CENTRAL LOCATION FOR RIDERS TO ACCESS PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION AND TRANSFER FROM VARIOUS COMMUNITY CONNECTOR ROUTES. THIS NEW TRANSIT CENTER WILL ALSO PROVIDE NEW TECHNOLOGY AND AMENITIES INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THE COMMUNITY CONNECTOR IS THE DESIGNED TRANSIT PROVIDER FOR THE CITIES OF BANGOR BREWER OLD TOWN AND THE TOWNS OF ORONO VEAZIE HAMPDEN AND THE UNIVERSITY OF MAINE. THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT THE RESIDENTS COMMUTERS AND TOURISTS OF THE COMMUNITY CONNECTORS SERVICE AREA.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: N/ATHE CITY OF BANGOR EXECUTED THE FY22 CERTIFICATIONS AND ASSURANCE IN TRAMS ON 08/08/2022. THE ACTIVITIES INCLUDED IN THIS GRANT ARE IN THE FY21 ELEMENT OF THE ME STIP. ALL ADMINISTRATIVE AND STATUTORY REQUIREMENTS HAVE BEEN MET IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE 5339 BUS AND BUS FACILITIES PROGRAM AS ARTICULATED IN FTA CIRCULAR 5100.1.

THE CITY OF BANGOR COMMUNITY CONNECTOR IS REQUESTING $238405 IN SECTION 5339 FORMULA FUNDS APPORTIONED TO BANGOR URBANIZED AREA. THE ENHANCEMENTS WILL ALSO IMPROVE OVERALL OPERATIONAL EFFICIENCY SECURITY AND CUSTOMER SATISFACTION BY DEPLOYING INTELLIGENT TRANSPORTATION SYSTEMS (ITS) TECHNOLOGIES ON FIXED-ROUTE AND PARATRANSIT SERVICES. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THE COMMUNITY CONNECTOR IS THE DESIGNED TRANSIT PROVIDER FOR THE CITIES OF BANGOR BREWER OLD TOWN AND THE TOWNS OF ORONO VEAZIE HAMPDEN AND THE UNIVERSITY OF MAINE. THIS APPLICATION IS TO REQUEST SECTION 5339 BUS AND BUS FACILITIES FORMULA FUNDS APPORTIONED TO THE STATE OF MAINE IN THE AMOUNT OF $3085679. THE REQUEST INCLUDES:FFY 2021 SECTION 5339 IN THE AMOUNT OF $3040120FFY 2022 SECTION 5339 IN THE AMOUNT OF $45559PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO PROVIDE THE STATE OF MAINE AND ITS SUBRECIPIENTS WITH 80% FEDERAL SHARE TO REPLACE BUSES TROLLEYS AND VANS BEYOND THEIR USEFUL LIFE AS WELL AS TO PURCHASE BUSES AND VANS TO EXPAND CURRENT FLEET SIZE FOR APPLICABLE TRANSIT PROVIDERS. IN ADDITION TWO FACILITIES WILL BE UPGRADED AND RENOVATED.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: FUNDS WILL BE USED TO PURCHASE BUSES CUTAWAYS TROLLEYS AND VANS FOR SUBRECIPIENTS AS WELL AS TO UPGRADE AND RENOVATE TWO FACILITIES.EXPECTED OUTCOMES: IMPROVE THE AVERAGE AGE OF THE FLEETS TO IMPROVE THE STATE OF GOOD REPAIR OF THE APPLICABLE MAINE TRANSIT PROVIDERS AS WELL AS IMPROVE THE EFFICIENCY OF THE FACILITIES AND ITS EQUIPMENT.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: EIGHT SUBRECIPIENTS AND THE POPULATIONS OF THEIR SERVICE AREAS THROUGHOUT THE STATE OF MAINE.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: ALL APPLICABLE SUBRECIPIENTS WILL RECEIVE FUNDS FOR CAPITAL ASSISTANCE AS OUTLINED IN THE ATTACHED PROGRAM OF PROJECTS. THE FOLLOWING TRANSIT PROVIDERS WILL RECEIVE FUNDING AS PART OF THIS AWARD.AROOSTOOK REGIONAL TRANSPORTATION SYSTEM (ARTS) FOR 3 ACCESSIBLE VANS AND 1 ACCESSIBLE CUTAWAY TO REPLACE TWO BUSES AND PURCHASE 2 ACCESSIBLE VANS TO EXPAND THEIR FLEET AS WELL AS FACILITY RENOVATIONS AND UPGRADES. DOWNEAST COMMUNITY PARTNERS (DCP) FOR 1 ACCESSIBLE CUTAWAY TO REPLACE 1 CUTAWAY.DOWNEAST TRANSPORTATION INC. (DTI) FOR 5 ACCESSIBLE CUTAWAYS TO REPLACE 5 BUSES.KENNEBEC VALLEY COMMUNITY ACTION PROGRAM (KVCAP) FOR 1 ACCESSIBLE CUTAWAY AND 2 ACCESSIBLE VANS TO REPLACE TWO NON-ACCESSIBLE VANS AND PURCHASE 1 CUTAWAY TO EXPAND THEIR FLEET.PENQUIS CAP (PENQUIS) FOR 3 ACCESSIBLE VANS TO REPLACE 3 VANS.REGIONAL TRANSPORTATION PROGRAM (RTP) FOR 8 ACCESSIBLE CUTAWAYS TO REPLACE 4 CUTAWAYS AND PURCHASE 4 CUTAWAYS TO EXPAND THEIR FLEET.WESTERN MAINE TRANSPORTATION SERVICES (WMTS) FOR FACILITY UPGRADES AND RENOVATIONS.YORK COUNTY COMMUNITY ACTION CORP. (YCCAC) FOR 5 TROLLEYS TO REPLACE 5 TROLLEYS.BENEFITS OF THE ABOVE ACTIVITIES: MANY OF MAINEDOTS TRANSIT PROVIDERS ARE USING ROLLING STOCK THAT IS BEYOND ITS USEFUL LIFE IN YEARS AND/OR MILES. IN ADDITION TO IMPROVING THE AVERAGE AGE OF THE FLEET THE MAINTENANCE COSTS OF OUR TRANSIT PROVIDERS SHOULD DECREASE WITH NEW VEHICLES. BUSES TROLLEYS AND VANS ARE BEING ACQUIRED TO COMPLY WITH OR MAINTAIN COMPLIANCE WITH ADA. MAINEDOT IS APPLYING FOR THESE VEHICLES AT 80% FEDERAL SHARE. THESE VEHICLES ARE REPLACING VEHICLES WHICH HAVE MET OR EXCEEDED THEIR USEFUL LIFE AND ARE FOR 7 NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS. REFER TO ATTACHED DOCUMENT WITH INFORMATION ON VEHICLES BEING REPLACED WHICH INCLUDES SUBRECIPIENT USEFUL LIFE MILEAGE YEAR/MAKE/MODEL AND VIN. THE NON-PROFITS WILL HOLD TITLE AND RECEIVE THE VEHICLES AS SUBRECIPIENTS. MAINEDOT WILL ENSURE THAT THE SUBRECIPIENTS WILL MAINTAIN SATISFACTORY CONTINUING CONTROL OF THE VEHICLES FUNDED. THESE ORGANIZATIONS AID THE SPECIAL TRANSPORTATION NEEDS OF SENIORS AND INDIVIDUALS WITH DISABILITIES IN THE STATE OF MAINE.LOCAL MATCH SOURCES INCLUDE COUNTY AND MUNICIPAL CONTRIBUTIONS CAPITAL RESERVE ACCOUNTS CONTRACTED SERVICES UNRESTRICTED FUNDS AND LOCAL BUSINESSES/CORPORATIONS.ALL VEHICLES ARE COMPETITIVELY BID AND AWARDED OR ADDED ON TO AN EXISTING CONTRACT. VEHICLES ARE PURCHASED THROUGH THE STATE OF MAINE BUREAU OF PURCHASES AND TITLED TO THE RESPECTIVE TRANSIT PROVIDERS NAMED IN THIS APPLICATION.ATTACHMENTS: (1) PROVIDER DESCRIPTION; (2) PROGRAM OF PROJECTS; (3) LOCAL SHARE MATCH LETTERS; (4) MAINEDOT LETTER ACCEPTING 5339 FUNDS FOR FFY2021 DATED APRIL 7 2021; AND (5) MAINEDOT LETTER ACCEPT 5339 FUNDS FOR FFY 2022. MAINEDOT EXECUTED THE FY2022 CERTIFICATIONS AND ASSURANCES IN TRAMS ON FEBRUARY 7 2022. ALL ACTIVITIES ARE PROGRAMMED IN THE FY22 ELEMENT OF THE CURRENT ME STIP. MAINEDOT IS CURRENT WITH ALL CIVIL RIGHTS REQUIREMENTS AND FTA ANNUAL CERTIFICATIONS. ALL ADMINISTRATIVE AND STATUTORY REQUIREMENTS HAVE BEEN MET IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE SECTION 5339 BUS AND BUS FACILITIES PROGRAM AS ARTICULATED IN FTA CIRCULAR 5100.1.ALL STATUTORY REQUIREMENTS HAVE BEEN MET.

MAINEDOT REQUESTS $769635 OF FFY2021 SECTION 5307 FORMULA FUNDS FROM THESE UZAS: PORTLAND DOVER-ROCHESTER AND PORTSMOUTH AND $80000 OF FFY2021 SECTION 5339 FUNDS FROM THE PORTLAND UZA.ACTIVITIES TO BE FUNDED ARE:OPERATING ASSISTANCEONGOING CONSTRUCTION EXPENSES AT RTPS ADMINISTRATION/MAINTENANCE FACILITY AT 1 LEDGEVIEW DRIVE IN WESTBROOKLOCAL MATCH WILL BE PROVIDED BY A COMBINATION OF SOURCES INCLUDING MAINEDOT YCCAC AND RTP. MAINEDOT EXECUTED ITS FFY2021 CERTIFICATION AND ASSURANCES IN TRAMS ON 1/25/2021. THESE PROJECTS ARE INCLUDED IN THE FFY2021 ELEMENT OF THE FY2021-2024 STIP. MAINEDOT IS CURRENT WITH ALL OF ITS CIVIL RIGHTS SUBMISSIONS. ALL ADMINISTRATIVE AND STATUTORY REQUIREMENTS HAVE BEEN MET IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE SECTIONS 5307 AND 5339 PROGRAMS.PERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 7/1/21 THROUGH 6/30/23PROJECT DESCRIPTION 1: SOUTHERN MAINE PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION (SMPDC) IN COOPERATION WITH THE KITTERY AREA COMPREHENSIVE TRANSPORTATION SYSTEM (KACTS) IS RECEIVING $193155 AS A SUB-RECIPIENT OF MAINEDOT. THIS APPLICATION IS FOR THE FFY 2021 APPORTIONMENT RELEASED FOR THE PORTSMOUTH AND DOVER-ROCHESTER URBAN AREAS IN MAINE (MINUS TRANSFER OF $95136 TO NH). SMPDC IS A COUNCIL OF GOVERNMENTS SERVING 39 MUNICIPALITIES IN SOUTHERN MAINE. SMPDC SERVES AS PRIMARY STAFF TO KACTS WHICH SERVES AS THE MPO SMPDC/KACTS IS FUNDING A CONTRACT FOR DEMAND RESPONSE TRANSPORTATION IN SOUTHERN MAINE WITHIN THE KACTS MPO. THE TRIPS ARE NON-MAINECARE (MEDICAID) ELIGIBLE TRIPS WHICH ARE COVERED UNDER A SEPARATE CONTRACT AND NOT FUNDED UNDER THIS APPLICATION. PROJECT DESCRIPTION 2: SUBRECIPIENT #1 -YORK COUNTY COMMUNITY ACTION CORPORATION (YCCAC) IS RECEIVING $378055 AS A SUBRECIPIENT OF MAINEDOT. YCCAC IS CONTINUING A JARC OPERATING PROJECT IN THE PORTLAND UZA. PER FTA CIRCULAR 9030.1E: WHILE THE SECTION 5316 JARC PROGRAM WAS REPEALED UNDER MAP-21 JOB ACCESS AND REVERSE COMMUTE PROJECTS ARE NOW AN ELIGIBLE PROJECT TYPE UNDER THE URBANIZED AREA FORMULA PROGRAM. (II-9). MAP-21 CREATED A NEW CATEGORY FOR JOB ACCESS AND REVERSE COMMUTE PROJECTS UNDER SECTION 5307. THERE IS NO SET-ASIDE OR CAP ON THE AMOUNT OF SECTION 5307 FUNDS THAT CAN BE USED FOR THESE PROJECTS. PRIVATE NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATIONS MAY RECEIVE FUNDING FOR JOB ACCESS AND REVERSE COMMUTE PROJECTS AS A SUBRECIPIENT OF AN FTA DESIGNATED RECIPIENT OR DIRECT RECIPIENT. (IV-18) THIS PROJECT IS ELIGIBLE AS A MAINTENANCE PROJECT WHEREBY MAINTENANCE OF TRANSPORTATION SERVICES MEANS PROJECTS THAT CONTINUE AND MAINTAIN JOB ACCESS AND REVERSE COMMUTE PROJECTS AND SERVICES THAT RECEIVED FUNDING UNDER THE FORMER SECTION 5316 PROGRAM. (IV-18) ON BEHALF OF THE GOVERNOR MAINEDOT IS THE DESIGNATED RECIPIENT OF SECTION 5307 FUNDS FOR JARC OPERATING PROJECTS PERFORMED BY NON-PROFIT AGENCIES. YCCAC IS A NON-PROFIT CORPORATION DESIGNATED BY MAINEDOT AS THE REGIONAL PROVIDER OF TRANSPORTATION SERVICES TO THE GENERAL PUBLIC INDIVIDUALS WITH DISABILITIES LOW INCOME AND ELDERLY PEOPLE IN TRANSIT REGION 8 WHICH INCLUDES YORK COUNTY. YCCAC PROVIDES FLEX ROUTE AND DEMAND RESPONSE SERVICES TO BOTH RURAL AND URBAN AREAS INCLUDING ROUTES IN THE TOWNS OF BIDDEFORD SACO AND OLD ORCHARD BEACH THAT ARE PART OF THE PORTLAND UZA AND NINE OXFORD COUNTY TOWNS. SUBRECIPIENT #2 - REGIONAL TRANSPORTATION PROGRAM (RTP) IS RECEIVING $198425 AS A SUBRECIPIENT OF MAINEDOT. RTP WILL USE THESE FUNDS FROM THE PORTLAND UZA APPORTIONMENT TO SUPPLEMENT GRANT FUNDS ALREADY PROVIDED UNDER ME-2020-015-01 FOR FACILITY CONSTRUCTION. MAINEDOT IS THE DESIGNATED RECIPIENT FOR NON-PROFIT AGENCIES. RTP IS A NON-PROFIT CORPORATION DESIGNATED BY MAINEDOT AS THE REGIONAL PROVIDER OF TRANSPORTATION SERVICES TO THE GENERAL PUBLIC INDIVIDUALS WITH DISABILITIES LOW INCOME AND ELDERLY PEOPLE IN TRANSIT REGION 6 WHICH INCLUDES CUMBERLAND COUNTY. RTP PROVIDES FLEX ROUTE AND DEMAND RESPONSE SERVICES TO BOTH RURAL AND URBAN AREAS IN CUMBERLAND COUNTY.PROJECT DESCRIPTION #3.REGIONAL TRANSPORTATION PROGRAM (RTP) IS RECEIVING $80000 AS A SUBRECIPIENT OF MAINEDOT. RTP WILL USE THESE FUNDS FROM THE PORTLAND UZA APPORTIONMENT TO SUPPLEMENT GRANT FUNDS ALREADY PROVIDED UNDER ME-2020-015-01 FOR FACILITY CONSTRUCTION. SPECIFICALLY THESE FUNDS WILL BE USED FOR MISCELLANEOUS EQUIPMENT TO BE HOUSED IN THE NEW ADMINISTRATION/MAINTENANCE FACILITY.MAINEDOT IS GUARANTEEING THE STATE MATCH OF $74591 FOR THE ABOVE ACTIVITIES. ALSO MAINEDOT HAS ON FILE THE APPROVED METHODOLOGY FOR THE IN-KIND MATCH THAT WILL BE USED BY YCCAC FOR ACTIVITIES IN THEIR REGION. MAINEDOT IS CURRENT WITH CIVIL RIGHTS REQUIREMENTS MILESTONE PROGRESS REPORTS AND FINANCIAL STATUS REPORTS. MAINEDOT EXECUTED THE FY2021 CERTIFICATIONS AND ASSURANCES ON 01/25/2021. THE ACTIVITIES INCLUDED IN THIS GRANT ARE INCLUDED IN THE FY2021 ELEMENT OF THE MAINE STIP. ALL ADMINISTRATIVE AND STATUTORY REQUIREMENTS HAVE BEEN MET IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE 5307 URBANIZED AREA FORMULA PROGRAM AS ARTICULATED IN FTA CIRCULAR 9030.1E.

ALL ADMINISTRATIVE AND STATUTORY REQUIREMENTS HAVE BEEN MET IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE SECTION 5339 BUS AND BUS FACILITIES PROGRAM AS ARTICULATED IN FTA CIRCULAR 5100.1.ALL STATUTORY REQUIREMENTS HAVE BEEN MET.

THIS IS A MASSACHUSETTS DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION (MASSDOT) REQUEST FOR $1838893 OF SECTION 5339 BUS BUS FACILITY FORMULA FUNDS (STATEWIDE AND SMALL URBAN FY14 AND FY15 APPORTIONMENTS) FOR A PROGRAM OF COMPETITIVELY CHOSEN CAPITAL BUS AND BUS FACILITY PROJECTS CONSISTING OF: 1) PURCHASE THIRTY BIKE RACKS AND FOUR STATIONARY COVERED RACKS/LOCKERS (MART) 2) REPLACE TWO (2) TYPE E2 PARATRANSIT VANS PAST THEIR USEFUL LIFE (MART) 3) FIFTY (50) BUS STOP ACCESSIBILITY IMPROVEMENTS (MBTA) 4) TWO (2) BUS STOPS ACCESSIBILITY IMPROVEMENTS (NRTA) 5) PURCHASE NEW FUEL MANAGEMENT SYSTEM (SRTA) AND 6) REPLACEMENT OF THE ORIGINAL ELEVATOR AND REPLACE CURBS AT THE NEW BEDFORD TERMINAL AT 134 ELM STREET (SRTA).THE TOTAL LOCAL MATCH OF 20% IS $459723.25 WHICH CONSISTS OF STATE TRANSPORTATION DEVELOPMENT (TOLL) CREDITS FOR SIX (6) PROJECTS. ON MARCH 12 2010 THE FHWA MA DIVISION OFFICE APPROVED THE MASSACHUSETTS DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATIONS REQUEST FOR USE OF UP TO $87.5M IN TOLL CREDITS TO DEFRAY NON-FEDERAL SHARE OF TRANSPORTATION PROJECTS (PLEASE SEE ATTACHED.) A NOTICE OF PROJECT SOLICITATION WAS POSTED BY MASSDOT ON ITS WEBSITE ON JANUARY 15 2015. THE NOTICE IDENTIFIED MARCH 2 2015 AS THE DATE THAT APPLICATIONS WERE DUE TO MASSDOT IN THE GRANTSPLUS SYSTEM. SIX APPLICANT TRAINING SESSIONS WERE HELD AT THE BEGINNING OF THE APPLICATION PROCESS. ON MARCH 24 2015 A TEAM CONSISTING OF MASSDOTOFFICE OF TRANSPORTATION PLANNING AND THE MASSDOT-TRANSIT DIVISION REVIEWED ALL 5339 APPLICATIONS AND RATED IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE PRIORITIES OF MASSDOTS CAPITAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM. ON 4/6/15 MASSDOT COMPETITIVELY SELECTED PROJECTS FOR FUNDING FOR THREE (3) STATEWIDE PROJECTS AND FOUR (4) SMALL URBAN PROJECTS.THE SELECTED PROJECTS WILL UTILIZE FUNDING AS FOLLOWS:STATEWIDE APPORTIONMENT:MASSACHUSETTS BAY TRANSIT AUTHORITY (MBTA): ACCESSIBILITY AND SAFETY IMPROVEMENTS AT FIFTY (50) BUS STOPS - - FFY15 CAPITAL FUNDS - - $1037306 (TWO YEAR PROJECT). NANTUCKET REGIONAL TRANSIT AUTHORITY (NRTA): TWO ACCESSIBLE RAMPS ALONG THE SOUTH SIDE OF ORANGE STREET AND IMPROVE ACCESSIBILITY BETWEEN BOTH CROSSWALKS AND HOUSING COMPLEX DRIVEWAYS - - FFY15 CAPITAL FUNDS - - $20000 (ONE YEAR PROJECT). SOUTHEASTERN REGIONAL TRANSIT AUTHORITY (SRTA): PURCHASE A NEW FUEL MANAGEMENT SYSTEM TO PROVIDE THE ABILITY TO RECORD MILEAGE FUEL AND FLUIDS TRACKING AND REPORTING - - FFY15 CAPITAL FUNDS $192694 (9 MONTHS). SMALL URBAN APPORTIONMENT:MONTACHUSETT REGIONAL TRANSIT AUTHORITY (MART): REPLACE TWO (2) 12 YEAR OLD PARATRANSIT VANS (30 FT.) WHICH ARE PAST THEIR USEFUL LIFE - - FFY15 CAPITAL FUNDS - - $115000 (EIGHT MONTH PROJECT).SOUTHEASTERN REGIONAL TRANSIT AUTHORITY (SRTA): REPLACE THE ORIGINAL ELEVATOR AND CURBS AT THE NEW BEDFORD TERMINAL AT 134 ELM STREET NEW BEDFORD MA - - FFY15 CAPITAL FUNDS - - $269587 (8 MONTHS). SOUTHEASTERN REGIONAL TRANSIT AUTHORITY (SRTA): PURCHASE A NEW FUEL MANAGEMENT SYSTEM TO PROVIDE THE ABILITY TO RECORD MILEAGE FUEL AND FLUIDS TRACKING AND REPORTING - - FFY15 CAPITAL FUNDS $154306 (9 MONTHS). MONTACHUSETT REGIONAL TRANSIT AUTHORITY (MART): PURCHASE THIRTY BUS RACKS AND FOUR STATIONARY COVERED RACKS/LOCKERS AT THEIR CUSTOMER TRANSIT FACILITIES - - FFY14 CAPITAL FUNDS $47592; FFY15 CAPITAL FUNDS $2408 TOTAL $50000 CAPITAL FUNDS (16 WEEKS).MASSDOT IS CHARGED WITH MANAGING ALL MODES OF TRANSPORTATION WITHIN THE COMMONWEALTH OF MASSACHUSETTS. MASSDOT HAS OVERSIGHT RESPONSIBILITY FOR THE MOTOR VEHICLES DIVISION THE HIGHWAY DIVISION AND THE RAIL TRANSIT DIVISION. MASSDOT PROVIDES FISCAL GUIDANCE AND OVERSIGHT OVER ALL FIFTEEN (15) REGIONAL TRANSIT AUTHORITIES (RTAS) PROVIDING LOCAL BUS TRANSIT ACROSS THE COMMONWEALTH. MASSDOT IS CURRENT WITH ALL CIVIL RIGHTS SUBMISSIONS AND FTA ANNUAL CERTIFICATIONS ACCORDING TO 49 USC SECTION 5339/ MAP-21 SECTION 20029. ALL ELEMENTS ARE INCLUDED IN THE FY15 STIP WHICH WAS APPROVED ON 10/29/14 AND STIP AMENDMENT #9 (APPROVED 8/13/15). APPLICATION PURPOSE: THE SOUTHEASTERN REGIONAL TRANSIT AUTHORITY (SRTA) WILL UTILIZE THIS AWARD FOR THE ACQUISITION OF EIGHTEEN (18) HYBRID ELECTRIC FIXED ROUTE BUSES. APPLICATION PURPOSE: MASSDOT REQUESTS $1186400 OF FFY20 FTA 5339 (A) BUS AND BUS FACILITIES FORMULA PROGRAM FUNDS (49 U.S.C. 5339 (A)) FOR THE COMPLETION OF THE CONSTRUCTION OF A NEW MAINTENANCE AND OPERATIONS FACILITY FOR THE FRANKLIN REGIONAL TRANSIT AUTHORITY (FRTA) LOCATED ON SANDY ROAD VILLAGE OF TURNER FALLS MONTAGUE MA. THIS FEDERAL REQUEST WILL BE MATCHED BY $796600 IN MASSDOT REGIONAL TRANSIT AUTHORITY CAPITAL FUNDS (RTACAP). UNDER PROJECT MA-34-0014 FTA PREVIOUSLY PROVIDED $6000000 OF FFY17 BUS AND BUS FACILITIES INFRASTRUCTURE INVESTMENT PROGRAM DISCRETIONARY (49 U.S.C.5339 (B) FOR THE PROJECT WHICH WAS MATCHED BY $3500000 OF MASSDOT RTACAP FUNDS. THE AMENDMENT WILL BRING THE TOTAL PROJECT COST TO $11483000 63% ($7186400) OF WHICH WILL BE FEDERAL FUNDING AND 37% ($4296600) WILL BE MASSDOT RTACAP FUNDS. MASSDOT ALSO PREVIOUSLY PROVIDED RTACAP FUNDS FOR ENGINEERING AND LAND ACQUISITION COSTS. THE FRTA CURRENTLY LEASES THEIR 100+ YEAR OLD MAINTENANCE FACILITY ON UNFAVORABLE TERMS. THE CURRENT FACILITY DOES NOT MEET THE MAINTENANCE AND OPERATING NEEDS OF THE AUTHORITY AND IS CONTINUING TO DETERIORATE. SINCE PROCEEDING WITH A CONSTRUCTION CONTRACT FOR THE NEW FACILITY IN DECEMBER 2021 THE FRTA HAS BEEN WORKING AGGRESSIVELY TO COMPLETE THE PROJECT. CONSTRUCTION OF THE NEW FRTA MAINTENANCE AND OPERATIONS FACILITY WILL GREATLY REDUCE ENERGY COSTS WITH A MODERN STRUCTURE WHICH UTILIZES ENERGY SAVING HEATING COOLING AND LIGHTING OPTIONS AND MATERIALS. THE NEW FACILITY WILL BE APPROXIMATELY 27700 SQUARE FEET ON A 5.05 ACRE PARCEL. THE FACILITY IS RIGHT-SIZED TO MEET THE NEEDS OF FRTA AND ITS TRANSIT PROGRAMS AND ALLOW FOR ALL TRANSIT VEHICLES TO BE STORED SECURED AND MAINTAINED INDOORS. THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO ALLOW FOR FUTURE EXPANSION. THE NEW FACILITY WILL BE FULLY ACCESSIBLE AND INCLUDE SPACE FOR A PUBLIC RECEPTION LOBBY FOR VISITORS AND DELIVERIES SEPARATE EMPLOYEE ENTRANCE LOST AND FOUND AREA COAT CLOSET MAIL/COPY ROOM SERVER ROOM CONFERENCE ROOM FILE STORAGE ROOM CASH COUNTING ROOM TRAINING AND BREAK AREA DRIVERS LOCKER AREA; ALL OF WHICH CURRENTLY FRTA DOESNT HAVE AND/OR DOUBLE WITH OTHER OPERATIONAL SPACE. CURRENTLY FRTA SERVERS AND OTHER IT EQUIPMENT ARE LOCATED IN THE GENERAL MANAGERS OFFICE THE CASH COUNTING ROOM SHARES THE SAME SPACE AS THE FAREBOX REPAIR SHOP AND EMPLOYEE TRAINING EITHER TAKES PLACE IN ONE OF THE MAINTENANCE BAYS OR MUST BE HOSTED OFF SITE. HAVING PROPER SPACE ADEQUATELY DESIGNED FOR SPECIFIC FUNCTIONS NOT ONLY SAVES TIME CONSTANTLY RECONFIGURING THE SPACE TO FIT THE DAILY NEEDS BUT ALSO PROVIDES A SAFER AND MORE SECURE WORK ENVIRONMENT WITH SPECIFIC USE DESIGN IN MIND. THE NEW PROPOSED PROJECT SITE IS LOCATED ALONG TWO FIXED ROUTE LINES AND FRTA IS ALREADY WORKING ON A PLAN TO INCORPORATE TRAVEL PATTERNS FOR THE REMAINDER OF ITS FIXED ROUTES BETWEEN THE MAINTENANCE AND OPERATIONS FACILITY AND ITS TRANSIT HUB TO MINIMIZE DEADHEAD TRAVEL COSTS. FRTA ALREADY HAS A FACILITIES MANAGER ON STAFF RESPONSIBLE FOR OVERSIGHT OF ALL FRTA REAL PROPERTY MAINTENANCE INSPECTIONS AND REPAIRS INCLUDING HVAC EQUIPMENT LIGHTING CONTROL ENERGY MANAGEMENT CCTV ACCESS CONTROL AND COMMUNICATIONS. MASSDOT HAS PROVIDED CONTINUOUS OVERSIGHT OF THE PROJECT TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH ALL FTA REQUIREMENTS.; ACTIVITIES PERFORMED: THIS AMENDMENT WILL PROVIDE AN ADDITIONAL $1983000 ($1186400 FEDERAL/$796600 MASSDOT RTA CAPITAL FUND RESOURCES) FOR THE COMPLETION OF THE FRANKLIN REGIONAL TRANSIT AUTHORITY (FRTA) NEW BUS MAINTENANCE AND OPERATIONS FACILITY. CONSTRUCTION OF THE FACILITY IS SUCCESSFULLY UNDERWAY UNDER FTA PROJECT MA-37-0014 AND IS EXPECTED TO BE COMPLETED IN THE SPRING OF 2023.THESE ADDITIONAL FUNDS ARE NEEDED PRIMARILY BECAUSE THE LOW BID FOR THE CONTRACT AWARDED IN DECEMBER 2021 DURING THE COVID PANDEMIC WAS APPROXIMATELY $800000 OVER THE DESIGN ESTIMATE. AS A CONSEQUENCE WHEN AWARDING THE CONSTRUCTION CONTRACT THE FRTA CARRIED THE $800000 AS AN ADDITIONAL FUTURE NEED UNDER PRE-AWARD AUTHORITY. IN ADDITION THE FRTA HAS EXPERIENCED OTHER UPWARD COST DRIVERS INCLUDING SOIL REMOVAL AND THE NEED FOR EXTRA FILL UNEXPECTED FOUNDATION COST INCREASES UTILITY COST INCREASES COVID PANDEMIC RELATED SUPPLY CHAIN CHALLENGES WITH MATERIAL DELIVERIES FIRE PROTECTION UPSIZING ADDITIONAL FENCING AND ASSOCIATED DESIGN AND PROJECT MANAGEMENT COST INCREASES. THE MASSDOT AND FRTA HAVE BEEN DILIGENTLY WORKING TO ADVANCE THIS PROJECT AND CONTROL COSTS. THIS AMENDMENT WILL ENABLE THE COMPLETION OF THE PROJECT. THE ADDITIONAL FUNDING PROVIDED UNDER THIS PROJECT WILL BE SOLELY USED TO COMPLETE ONGOING CONSTRUCTION WORK FOR THE NEW MAINTENANCE AND OPERATIONS FACILITY WITHIN THE EXISTING PROJECT FOOTPRINT WHICH WAS COVERED UNDER THE CATEGORICAL EXCLUSION (CE) FOR THE FACILITY PROJECT APPROVED BY FTA ON 6/16/2021.; EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THIS AMENDMENT WILL PROVIDE AN ADDITIONAL $1983000 ($1186400 FEDERAL/$796600 MASSDOT RTA CAPITAL FUND RESOURCES) FOR THE COMPLETION OF THE FRANKLIN REGIONAL TRANSIT AUTHORITY (FRTA) NEW MAINTENANCE AND OPERATIONS FACILITY. THE NEW PROPOSED PROJECT SITE IS LOCATED ALONG TWO FIXED ROUTE LINES AND FRTA IS ALREADY WORKING ON A PLAN TO INCORPORATE TRAVEL PATTERNS FOR THE REMAINDER OF ITS FIXED ROUTES BETWEEN THE MAINTENANCE AND OPERATIONS FACILITY AND ITS TRANSIT HUB TO MINIMIZE DEADHEAD TRAVEL COSTS. FRTA ALREADY HAS A FACILITIES MANAGER ON STAFF RESPONSIBLE FOR OVERSIGHT OF ALL FRTA REAL PROPERTY MAINTENANCE INSPECTIONS AND REPAIRS INCLUDING HVAC EQUIPMENT LIGHTING CONTROL ENERGY MANAGEMENT CCTV ACCESS CONTROL AND COMMUNICATIONS. POLICIES AND PROCEDURES FOR KEEPING ALL OF THE FRTAS REAL PROPERTY AND FLEET VEHICLES ARE REVIEWED WITH MASSDOT TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH MAINTAINING RESOURCES IN A STATE OF GOOD REPAIR AND FOLLOWING BEST INDUSTRY PRACTICES.; SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NONE

APPLICATION PURPOSE: THIS IS A CAPE COD REGIONAL TRANSIT AUTHORITY (CCRTA) REQUEST FOR $676550 IN FEDERAL FUNDS CONSISTING OF 2020 CARRYOVER 5339 FUNDS FOR THE BARNSTABLE-MA UZA FOR A PROGRAM OF CAPITAL PROJECTS WHICH WILL HELP FACILITATE MAINTAINING OUR SERVICE AS WELL AS ACCELERATE THE CONVERSION OF THE CCRTA FLEET TO ZERO-EMISSIONS VEHICLES.; ACTIVITIES PERFORMED: THESE FUNDS WILL BE USED TO BEGIN THE ELECTRIFICATION PROCESS OF CONVERTING THE CCRTA TO A ZERO-EMISSION FLEET.; EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE PRIMARY FOCUS OF THIS EFFORT WILL BE TO MODERNIZE THE FLEET WITH ZERO-EMISSION VEHICLES WHICH ARE IN DEMAND IN AN AREA AS ENVIRONMENTALLY CONSCIOUS AS CAPE COD. BOTH EFFICIENCY AND EMISSION REDUCTION ARE OBVIOUS ADVANTAGES BUT WE WOULD EXPECT FURTHER TO BE A LEADER AMONG TRANSPORTATION PROVIDERS IN THE AREA BY PROVIDING SUPPORT TO OTHERS IN THEIR EFFORTS TO ELECTRIFY THEIR FLEETS.; INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THE BENEFICIARIES OF THIS EFFORT WILL BE THE RIDERS WHO USE OUR SERVICE BUT THE REDUCED EMISSIONS WE EXPECT TO DELIVER WILL BENEFIT ALL CITIZENS IN OUR AREA AND BEYOND.; SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES DIRECTLY RELATED TO THIS EFFORT.

APPLICATION PURPOSE: METROWEST REGIONAL TRANSIT AUTHORITY (MWRTA) REQUESTS $330000 OF FFY 2020 5339 BUS AND BUS FACILITIES STATEWIDE FUNDS TO SUPPORT THE REPLACEMENT OF VEHICLES TO MWRTAS FLEET. PURPOSE: THE SOUTHEASTERN REGIONAL TRANSIT AUTHORITY IS REQUESTING A TOTAL OF $147109 OF FEDERAL FUNDS FOR THE PURPOSES OF PROVIDING CAPITAL PROJECTS AS OUTLINED BELOW.THE REQUEST FOR FUNDING SHALL BE COMPRISED OF THE FOLLOWING:* PROVIDENCE FFY19 URBANIZED AREA (UZA) 5339: $147109 (SPLIT LETTER DATED 05/08/2019 ATTACHED)ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:* REPAIRS TO THE NORTH FACADE OF SRTAS NEW BEDFORD TERMINAL. ALL REPAIRS WILL BE ADA COMPLIANT.EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THIS PROJECT WILL IMPROVE THE STATE OF GOOD REPAIR FOR TRANSIT ASSETS (FACILITIES) AT THE SRTA IN ADDITION TO INCREASING SAFETY ENHANCING OPERATIONS AND ALLOWING FOR CONTINUED CAPITAL PLANNING EFFORTS.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: POPULACE OF SRTAS SERVICE AREA AND LOCAL AREA COMMUTERS.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NONETHE SRTA SERVES THE TOWNS OF ACUSHNET DARTMOUTH FAIRHAVEN FALL RIVER MATTAPOISETT NEW BEDFORD SOMERSET SWANSEA AND WESTPORT. THE AUTHORITY CURRENTLY OPERATES 24 FIXED ROUTES WITHIN THIS DEFINED SERVICE AREA IN ADDITION TO ADA PARATRANSIT AND EXPANDED ADA PARATRANSIT SERVICES. THE SRTA HUB AND SPOKE STYLE SYSTEMS ARE DESIGNED AROUND TWO (2) PASSENGER TERMINALS - NEW BEDFORD AND FALL RIVER. THE SRTA PROVIDES BOTH FIXED ROUTE AND PARATRANSIT / DEMAND RESPONSE SERVICE MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY FROM 6:00AM TO 10:00PM AND SATURDAY FROM 6:00AM TO 8:00PM. PARATRANSIT SERVICE / DEMAND RESPONSE IS PROVIDED ON SUNDAYS 9:00AM TO 6:00PM.THE SRTA EXECUTED THE FFY22 CERTIFICATIONS AND ASSURANCES IN TRAMS ON 2/4/2022. THE ACTIVITIES IN THIS GRANT ARE INCLUDED IN THE FY22 ELEMENT OF THE MA STIP. THE SRTA IS CURRENT WITH ALL CIVIL RIGHTS SUBMISSIONS. ALL ADMINISTRATIVE AND STATUTORY REQUIREMENTS HAVE BEEN MET IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE SECTION 5307 URBANIZED AREA FORMULA PROGRAM AS ARTICULATED IN FTA CIRCULAR 9030.1E.

THIS APPLICATION IS TO REQUEST FFY 2019 SECTION 5339 FUNDS APPORTIONED TO THE COMMONWEALTH OF MASSACHUSETTS IN THE AMOUNT OF $388250 WHICH WAS DESIGNATED AS PART OF A LOW/NO GRANT AWARD. THESE FUNDS WILL BE MATCHED WITH LOCAL FUNDS AS APPROVED BY THE STEAMSHIP AUTHORITY BOARD OF GOVERNORS AND USED TO PAY THE INCREMENTAL COSTS OF PURCHASING TWO ELECTRIC TRANSIT BUSES TO BE USED FOR TRANSPORTING STEAMSHIP PASSENGERS FROM PARKING LOTS IN FALMOUTH TO THE WOODS HOLE FERRY TERMINAL. PURPOSE: THESE FUNDS WILL BE USED TO PAY THE INCREMENTAL COST OF UPGRADING THE BUS FROM DIESEL TO AN ALL ELECTRIC BUS. THE BUSES WILL BE REPLACING TWO BUSES CURRENTLY IN USE THAT HAVE REACHED THE END OF THEIR USEFUL LIFE.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE BUSES TO BE PURCHASED HAVE BEEN PROCURED THROUGH BUILD YOUR DREAMS MOTORS (BYD) AS THEIR PREFERRED VENDOR FOR ALL-ELECTRIC BUS TECHNOLOGIES AFTER A COMPETITIVE BID PROCESS. AFTER BEING PLACED INTO SERVICE THESE BUSES WILL BE USED TO PROVIDE TRANSPORTATION BETWEEN PARKING LOTS IN HYANNIS TO THE LOCAL FERRY DOCK OR FALMOUTH TO THE FERRY DOCK IN WOODS HOLE.EXPECTED OUTCOMES: REDUCED ENERGY CONSUMPTION; REDUCED VEHICLE EMISSIONS; REDUCED CARBON EMISSIONS; AND LOWER MAINTENANCE COSTS.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THE SERVICE IS OPEN TO THE PUBLIC SO AVAILABLE TO ANY RESIDENTS OR VISITORS TO CAPE COD.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: ALL ACTIVITIES UNDER THIS GRANT WILL BE PERFORMED BY THE STEAMSHIP AUTHORITY AS A SUBRECIPIENT TO THE CAPE COD REGIONAL TRANSIT AUTHORITY OVERSIGHT.

THIS APPLICATION IS TO REQUEST FFY 2019 SECTION 5339 FUNDS APPORTIONED TO THE BARNSTABLE UZA IN THE AMOUNT OF $424977. ADDITIONALLY CCRTA WILL MATCH THESE FUNDS WITH $106245 IN MASSACHUSETTS RTACAP TO COMPLETE THE FINANCING. THE GRANT FUNDS ADVANCE A PROGRAM OF CAPITAL THAT WILL ENABLE CCRTA TO BEGIN A MIGRATION OF FOSSIL FUELED TRANSPORTATION VEHICLES TO AN ALL ELECTRIC VEHICLE. PREVIOUS INVESTMENTS IN ELECTRIC INFRASTRUCTURE FUNDED BY FTA AND MASSDOT AS WELL AS COOPERATIVE PUBLIC/PRIVATE EFFORTS WITH BUSINESS PARTNERS HAS ENABLED US TO OPERATE THESE VEHICLES IMMEDIATELY FROM THE HYANNIS TRANSPORTATION CENTER AND MANAGE THE ELECTRICAL CHARGING NEEDS WITHOUT ADDITIONAL INVESTMENT. THIS WILL ALLOW THE CCRTA TO CONTINUE PROVIDING A RELIABLE RESPONSIVE AND SAFE SERVICE TO THE PUBLIC THAT WILL HELP KEEP EXISTING RIDERS AND ATTRACT NEW RIDERS. FOLLOWING IS A LISTING OF THE PROJECT FUNDED UNDER THIS APPLICATION AS WELL AS NESTED ACTIVITIES:PROJECT: SECTION 5339 ACQUISITION OF VEHICLES AND EQUIPMENT(1A) ACQUISITION OF SEVEN (7) ELECTRIC MINI-VAN BUSES TO BE PLACED INTO SERVICE REPLACING EXISTING GASOLINE POWERED MINI-VANS FOR ON-DEMAND SERVICE ON CAPE COD. INITIAL SERVICE AREA INCLUDES THE TOWNS OF BARNSTABLE AND YARMOUTH WITH EXPANSION OF THE SERVICE AREA PLANNED FOR 2023 TO ADDITIONAL AREAS ON CAPE COD. TOTAL PROJECT COST = $531222ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: SEVEN ELECTRIC MINI-VANS WILL BE REPLACING THE EXISTING GASOLINE POWERED MINI-VANS THAT OPERATE THE ON-DEMAND SERVICE IN AND AROUND THE HYANNIS AREA OF CAPE COD.EXPECTED OUTCOMES: CUSTOMERS ARE DEMANDING MORE ENVIRONMENTALLY RESPONSIBLE TRANSPORTATION OPTIONS ON CAPE COD AND THE CCRTA PLANS TO CONTINUE PROVIDING THESE OPTIONS. IT IS OUR EXPECTATION THAT THE AVAILABILITY OF THESE VEHICLES ALONG WITH A SIGNIFICANT MEDIA PROMOTION WILL DRIVE RIDERSHIP AND ALLOW US TO EXPAND THE PROGRAM TO THE REST OF CAPE COD.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: POPULACE OF THE CCRTA SERVICE AREA AND LOCAL AREA COMMUTERS.SUBRECIPIENTS: NONE

THE GREATER ATTLEBORO TAUNTON REGIONAL TRANSIT AUTHORITY (GATRA) REQUESTS A TOTAL OF $915031 FEDERAL FUNDS TO PURCHASE A 35-FOOT ACCESSIBLE ELECTRIC BUS. THIS APPLICATION REQUESTS A TOTAL OF $132000000 FEDERAL FUNDS FROM THE SECTION 5307 AND SECTION 5339 PROGRAMS.SECTION 5307 URBANIZED AREA FORMULA PROGRAMFFY 2021 - $33638796FFY 2022 - $87205859TOTAL - $120844655SECTION 5339 - BUS AND BUS FACILITIESFFY 2021 - $5301737FFY 2022 - $5853608TOTAL - $11155345LOCAL MATCH WILL BE FROM MBTA REVENUE BONDS.PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO SUPPORT THE PROCUREMENT OF 160 (BASE ORDER) 40-FT ENHANCED ELECTRIC HYBRID (EEH) BUSES TO REPLACE THE AGING 310 NEW FLYER 40 DIESEL BUS FLEET PURCHASED IN 2006-2008 SUPPORTING RELIABLE AND MORE EFFICIENT OPERATIONS. THIS PROGRAM WILL SUPPORT THE AUTHORITYS TARGET OF PROCURING 80X VEHICLES ANNUALLY.THE SCOPE OF THIS BUS FLEET PROCUREMENT ALSO INCLUDES RFP PUBLICATION DESIGN REVIEW PILOT BUS PRODUCTION AND TESTING FIRST ARTICLE INSPECTION PROCESS SERIAL PRODUCTION FLEET COMMISSIONING WARRANTY SUPPORT (1 YEAR) AND PROJECT CLOSEOUT. THIS IS ENCOMPASSED ACROSS THE BASE ORDER OF 160 40FT BUSES AND OPTION PURCHASES FOR UP TO AN ADDITIONAL 300 VEHICLES.EXPECTED OUTCOMES: AS THE 2006-2008 NEW FLYER 40 BUS FLEET CONTINUES TO AGE BUS OPERATIONS WILL EXPERIENCE A DEGRADATION OF SERVICE QUALITY INCREASED OPERATING COSTS AND INCREASED SAFETY CONCERNS TO CUSTOMERS AND OPERATORS AND ULTIMATELY INCREASED CUSTOMER DISSATISFACTION. FUNDING THIS PROCUREMENT PROGRAM AND REPLACEMENT OF OLDER FLEETS WILL HAVE A POSITIVE EFFECT ON REPAIR TIMES BASED OFF THEIR CUMULATIVE YEARLY MILEAGE. ADDITIONALLY THIS PROGRAM ALLOWS THE MBTA TO ESTABLISH STEADY AND CONSISTENT PROCUREMENT OF NEW FLEETS AND REPLACEMENT OF AGING FLEETS LEADING TO NORMALIZED PM CYCLES MID-LIFE OVERHAULS UPGRADE CAMPAIGNS STABILIZED OPERATIONS ETC.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: POPULACE OF THE MBTA TRANSIT SERVICE AREA AND LOCAL AREA COMMUTERS.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NONEPROJECT IS ON THE FY22-26 TIP UNDER THE 5307 REVENUE VEHICLE PROGRAM.

APPLICATION PURPOSE: METROWEST REGIONAL TRANSIT AUTHORITY (MWRTA) WILL PROCURE REPLACEMENT VEHICLES TO SUPPORT THE FLEET.; ACTIVITIES PERFORMED: MWRTA WILL PROCURE CNG VEHICLE REPLACEMENT VEHICLES.; EXPECTED OUTCOMES: BENEFITS: RESEARCH HAS SHOWN THAT CARBON MONOXIDE IS THE MAIN COMPONENT OF THE HARMFUL GASSES EMITTED. THE EMISSION OF HARMFUL GAS IS LOWERED BY 80% FOR THE VEHICLES RUNNING ON CNG. CNG VEHICLES ALSO PRODUCE 45% LESSER HYDROCARBONS THAN OTHER FUEL TYPES. THEREFORE AS MORE AND MORE INDIVIDUALS MOVE TO CNG THE TOTAL AMOUNT OF HARMFUL GAS EMISSIONS WILL REDUCE AND POSITIVELY IMPACT THE ENVIRONMENT. CNG IS AN AFFORDABLE ALTERNATIVE TO OTHER EXPENSIVE FUEL TYPES LIKE DIESEL AND GASOLINE. THE USE OF CNG AS A FUEL HAS INCREASED. ALONG WITH THIS SEVERAL TECHNOLOGICAL ADVANCEMENTS HAVE HELPED MANUFACTURERS LAUNCH VEHICLES THAT FUNCTION EFFICIENTLY WITH CNG. CNG HAS BECOME A MORE AFFORDABLE FUEL OPTION OVER THE PAST FEW YEARS AND IS CONSIDERED AMONG THE CLEANEST FUEL TYPES BECAUSE CNG LEAVES MINIMAL RESIDUE COMPARED TO OTHER FUEL TYPES LIKE DIESEL OR PETROL. IN ADDITION THE MINIMAL AMOUNT OF RESIDUE RESULTS IN MINIMAL DAMAGE TO THE TUBES AND PIPES OF THE ENGINE. CONSEQUENTLY THE FUNCTIONALITY OF THE ENGINE IMPROVES AND ITS LIFESPAN INCREASES. LOW CONTAMINATION ALSO ENSURES THAT VEHICLES DO NOT INCUR FREQUENT MECHANICAL ISSUES. WITH REGARD TO SAFETY CNG IS IN A GASEOUS FORM. IT SMOOTHLY DISPERSES IF THERE IS A LEAK AND DOES NOT SPILL IN OR ON YOUR CAR WHICH MAY CREATE A FIRE HAZARD. CNG IS LIGHTER THAN AIR AND IF IT BEGINS TO LEAK IT WILL MOVE AWAY FROM YOUR VEHICLE.; INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THIS PROCUREMENT WILL BENEFIT PASSENGERS TAKING PUBLIC TRANSIT WITHIN THE METROWEST RTA SERVICE AREA.; SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NONE.

THIS APPLICATION IS FOR 2018 5339 FUNDS TO ASSIST WITH THE CONSTRUCTION OF THE DOWNTOWN TERMINAL. THE EXISTING FACILITY LOCATED AT 207 CATALPA STREET IN MONROE LOUISIANA WAS BUILT IN 1987 AND HAS PHYSICALLY DETERIORATED SINCE THAT TIME. AFTER MORE THAN 30 YEARS OF OPERATION THE NEED FOR REPAIRS HAS RAPIDLY INCREASED TO A POINT THAT REPLACEMENT IS NOW PREFERRED OVER CONTINUED MAINTENANCE. CURRENTLY THE FACILITY IS NOT DISASTER RESILIENT NOR DOES IT PROVIDE SUFFICIENT SHELTER SPACE IN THE EVENT OF AN EXTREME WEATHER EVENT SUCH AS A TORNADO OR MICRO-BURST. RECENT REPAIRS INCLUDE A MINOR RENOVATION IN 2011 THE REPLACEMENT OF HVAC SYSTEMS IN 2013 AND PAVEMENT AND ROOF REPAIRS IN 2015. NOT ONLY WILL IT PROVIDE SERVICE FOR OUR CURRENT FIXED ROUTE SERVICE THE NEW FACILITY WILL FACILITATE MULTI-MODAL CONNECTIVITY. THE MULTI-MODAL INCLUSION WILL FEATURE DIRECT ACCESS TO BICYCLE/PEDESTRIAN FACILITIES AND CLOSE PROXIMITY TO A PROPOSED PASSENGER RAIL LINE. ADDITIONALLY IT WILL CONTINUE TO PROVIDE CONNECTIVITY WITH GREYHOUND LINES WHICH HAS BEEN HOUSED IN THE CURRENT FACILITY SINCE LATE 2018. THE CURRENT FACILITY IS SERVICED BY LOCAL CAB COMPANIES AND LOUISIANA TRANSIT THE ADJACENT RURAL TRANSIT AGENCY. SUCH CONNECTIONS WILL DIRECTLY IMPACT ENVIRONMENTAL SUSTAINABILITY BY REDUCING EMISSIONS CAUSED BY SINGLE-OCCUPANT VEHICLE TRIPS AND TRAFFIC CONGESTION.THE LOCATION OF THE REPLACEMENT PASSENGER TERMINAL CONSISTS OF 3 PARCELS TOTALING 2.184 ACRES FACING DESIARD STREET IN MONROE LOUISIANA. THE SITE IS ADJACENT TO CHURCHS CHICKEN AT 1690 DESIARD ST MONROE LA 71201 AND DIRECTLY IN FRONT OF THE QUACHITA PARISH HEALTH UNIT AT 1650 DESIARD ST MONROE LA 71201. IT IS LOCATED 0.9 MILES EAST OF THE CURRENT PASSENGER TERMINAL LOCATION. THE CITY WILL BE PURCHASING THIS PROPERTY FOR THIS PROJECT.THE CITY OF MONROE IS REQUESTING $323996 FOR CONSTRUCTION TO REPLACE THE INTERMODAL DOWNTOWN TRANSIT TERMINAL. THESE ARE 2018 FUNDS ALLOCATED THROUGH THE LOUISIANA DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION AND DEVELOPMENT FOR CONSTRUCTION TO REPLACE THE DOWNTOWN TRANSIT TERMINAL. LOCAL FUNDING OF $80999 WILL COME FROM THE CITY OF MONROES GENERAL FUND.THIS GRANT DOES NOT FULLY FUND THE $5 MILLION-DOLLAR PROJECT; HOWEVER THE CITY OF MONROE HAS INCORPORATED OTHER AVAILABLE OPPORTUNITIES TO SECURE FUNDING. THOSE OPPORTUNITIES ARE:1. SECURED $880000 OF THE REQUIRED $4 MILLION OF FEDERAL FUNDING WITH 5339 GRANT LA 2019-024-00. THIS WAS RECEIVED THROUGH THE LOUISIANA DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION AND DEVELOPMENT. APPLICATION COST - TOTAL $1100000; LOCAL SHARE $220000; FEDERAL SHARE $8800002. SECURED $1500000 OF THE REQUIRED $4 MILLION OF FEDERAL FUNDING WITH 5339 GRANT LA 2019-027-00. THIS WAS RECEIVED THROUGH THE LOUISIANA DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION AND DEVELOPMENT. APPLICATION COST - TOTAL $1875000; LOCAL SHARE $375000; FEDERAL SHARE $1500000.3. SECURED $658613 OF THE REQUIRED $4 MILLION OF FEDERAL FUNDING WITH GRANT LA-2021-034-00. APPLICATION PURPOSE: KENTUCKY TRANSPORTATION CABINETAPPLICATION FOR SECTION 5339(B) FY22 COMPETITIVE FUNDINGPURPOSE: IS TO SECURE THE 5339(B) FFY22 FUNDING FOR SECTION 5311 AGENCIES. TO SECURE FUNDS FOR (12) REPLACEMENT VANS (35) EXPANSION VEHICLES IN ORDER TO MAINTAIN FLEET AND EXPAND SERVICES (92) TABLETS; (2) SOFTWARE PACKAGES; (1) SECURITY/CAMERA SYSTEM AND (1) RESURFACE/PAVING LOT LOCATED AT 332 HOOD AVENUE LEBANON KY 40033.CKCAC HAS BEEN EXPERIENCING MANY ISSUES WITH THEIR CURRENT SOFTWARE AND CUSTOMER SERVICE HAS BEEN NON-EXISTENT. CKCAC STILL USES MANY PAPER MANIFESTS FOR THEIR DRIVERS MANUALLY ENTER TRIPS INTO THEIR CURRENT SOFTWARE AND MANUALLY SCHEDULE TRIPS. THEIR CAMERA SYSTEM IS OUTDATED AND CANNOT BE VIEWED UNLESS THE TAPE IS PULLED FROM THE VEHICLE. THIS INVOLVES TRAVELING TO THE COUNTY IN WHICH THE VEHICLE IS LOCATED AND BRINGING THE TAPE BACK TO CENTRAL OFFICE FOR VIEWING. CKCAC NEEDS THIS FUNDING TO SWITCH TO A DIFFERENT SOFTWARE WHERE THEIR TRIPS CAN BE CONVERTED OVER WITHOUT HAVING TO MANUALLY ENTER THEM. THEY ALSO WANT TO ADD NEW CAMERA SYSTEMS TO REPLACE OLD AND OUTDATED CAMERAS. THE NEW CAMERA SYSTEM WILL INCLUDE LIVE VIEW WITH A SOFTWARE FOR DRIVERS TO USE IN PLACE OF PAPER MANIFESTS ALONG WITH VEHICLE MAINTENANCE SUPPORT. THE DRIVERS WILL HAVE TABLETS PLACED IN EACH VEHICLE TO BE USED FOR MASS TEXTING AND AUTOMATIC SCHEDULING. THE CHANGES WILL IMPROVE AND UPDATE THE OVERALL OPERATIONS OF CKCAC IMPROVE SECURITY OF THE VEHICLES CLIENTS AND DRIVERS AND WILL SAVE CKCAC TIME AND MONEY.; ACTIVITIES PERFORMED: PURCHASE OF:FEDERAL SHARE $542765 (12) REPLACEMENT VANS $2483643 (35) EXPANSION VANS $43173 (92) TABLETS $43109 (2) SOFTWARE PACKAGES $93030 (1) SECURITY SYSTEM $59872 (1) BLACK TOP/PAVING LOT) LOCATED AT 332 HOOD AVENUE LEBANON KY 40033. $3265592 FEDERAL SHARE; EXPECTED OUTCOMES: PURCHASE VANS TO MAINTAIN FLEETS AND EXPAND TO OTHER AREAS OF NEEDS NEW TABLETS SOFTWARE FOR MORE EFFICIENT OPERATIONS ADD SECURITY RESTORE PARKING AREA FOR VEHICLES.; INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: TRANSIT OPERATORS GENERAL PUBLICTHE TABLETS WILL BENEFIT IN THE COMMUNICATION BETWEEN THE DRIVERS AND DISPATCH. THIS SHOULD ALLOW FOR MORE INFORMATION FOR THE PASSENGERS.; SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: ACTUAL REQUEST PROCUREMENT APPROVALS MAKE PROCUREMENTS INSTALL EQUIPMENT REQUEST REIMBURSEMENT.

APPLICATION PURPOSE: THIS AWARD FUNDS MANY TRANSPORTATION PROJECTS THAT WILL ADDRESS THE CONDITION OF TARCS MOST SIGNIFICANT ASSETS. IT ALSO FUNDS IN PART OUR PARATRANSIT SERVICE.; ACTIVITIES PERFORMED: WITH THE FORMULA FUNDS IDENTIFIED IN THE APPLICATION TARC WILL: REPLACE BUSES THAT ARE WELL PAST THEIR EXPECTED MINIMUM LIFE; REPLACE THE 15 YEAR-OLD OPERATIONAL SOFTWARE THAT ALLOWS US TO DISPATCH OUR BUSES AND TO KNOW WHERE THEY ARE IN REAL TIME; BETTER PROTECT OUR ASSETS BY UPGRADING OUR FACILITY SURVEILLANCE AND ACCESS CONTROL SYSTEMS; REPLACE THE 25 YEAR-OLD HEATING AND VENTILATING SYSTEM IN OUR BUS STORAGE FACILITY IMPROVE OUR BUS OPERATOR TRAINING FACILITY AND REHABILITATE OUR SMALL VEHICLE REPAIR FACILITY; SUPPORT OUR MAINTENANCE AND PARATRANSIT SERVICE; SUPPORT OUR PURCHASE OF SIX NEW LONG RANGE BATTERY ELECTRIC BUSES; AND CONTINUE TO IMPROVE THE BOARDING AREAS AND SIDEWALKS ALONG OUR BUS ROUTES.; EXPECTED OUTCOMES: AS A RESULT OF THE PROJECTS FUNDED BY THIS AWARD THE CONDITION OF TARCS FIXED ROUTE FLEET WILL IMPROVE ITS DISPATCHING AND PASSENGER INFORMATION WILL BE MORE ROBUST AND HELPFUL AND SOME OF OUR MOST IMPORTANT FACILITIES WILL BECOME MORE EFFICIENT AND PRODUCTIVE.; INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: TARCS CUSTOMERS AND EMPLOYEES ALONG WITH ALL MEMBERS OF OUR COMMUNITY WILL BENEFIT FROM THE PROJECTS FUNDED BY THIS AWARD.; SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NO SUBRECIPIENT PROJECTS WILL BE FUNDED THROUGH THIS GRANT.

THIS APPLICATION IS TO REQUEST SECTION 5307 AND 5339 FUNDS APPORTIONED TO THE EVANSVILLE UZA IN THE AMOUNT OF $520394. THIS APPLICATION REQUESTS FUNDING FOR MULTIPLE PROJECTS INCLUDING OPERATING ASSISTANCE ADA PARATRANSIT SERVICE PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE AND PLANNING ASSISTANCE FOR HARTS FY 2022 STARTING JULY 1 2021. THESE PROJECTS WILL BE IMPLEMENTED FROM JULY 1 2021 TO JULY 1 2023. THIS APPLICATION ALSO REQUESTS FUNDING FOR A SUPPORT VEHICLE THAT WAS DELIVERED JANUARY 26 2022. THIS GRANT APPLICATION IS FOR A TOTAL OF $668280 WITH $520394 IN FEDERAL FUNDS $117689 IN STATE FUNDS AND $30197 IN LOCAL MATCH. THE FEDERAL FUNDS ARE FROM THE FOLLOWING PROGRAMS: - FFY 2020 SECTION 5307 FUNDS IN THE AMOUNT OF $358062. - FFY 2021 SECTION 5307 FUNDS IN THE AMOUNT OF $146410. - FFY 2021 SECTION 5339 FUNDS IN THE AMOUNT OF $15922.STATE FUNDS ARE FROM THE KENTUCKY TRANSPORTATION CABINET. LOCAL FUNDS ARE FROM THE CITY OF HENDERSON GENERAL FUND.PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS APPLICATION IS TO PROVIDE UP TO 2 YEARS OF OPERATING ASSISTANCE ADA PARATRANSIT SERVICE PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE AND PLANNING ASSISTANCE FOR HART FROM JULY 1 2021 TO JULY 1 2023. THIS APPLICATION WILL ALSO FUND A NEW SERVICE VEHICLE TO REPLACE A SERVICE VEHICLE PAST ITS USEFUL LIFE.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: OPERATING AND ADA FUNDS WILL BE USED TO COVER ALL ELIGIBLE OPERATING EXPENSES SUCH AS DRIVER SALARIES FUEL INSURANCE AND OTHER ITEMS HAVING A USEFUL LIFE OF LESS THAN ONE YEAR. PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE FUNDS WILL BE USED FOR SCHEDULED INSPECTIONS FLUIDS FILTERS AND OTHER ROUTINE PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE ACTIVITIES. PLANNING FUNDS WILL BE USED FOR PLANNING ACTIVITIES BY THE EVANSVILLE MPO. THE SUPPORT VEHICLE WILL BE USED BY HART STAFF TO GO TO ACCIDENTS CHECK ROADS IN BAD WEATHER AND CHANGE OUT BUS DRIVERS AT THE TERMINAL. APPLICATION EXECUTIVE SUMMARYTHIS APPLICATION WILL COMBINE AWARDS FROM TWO SOURCES OF FUNDING. INCLUDED ARE FFY 2019 CMAQ FUNDS AWARDED TO TARC BY THE COMMONWEALTH OF KENTUCKY THAT HAVE BEEN FLEXED TO THE SECTION 5307 PROGRAM AS WELL AS AN AWARD FROM THE SECTION 5339(C) FFY 2021 LOW OR NO EMISSIONS VEHICLE PROGRAM LONO D2021-LWNO-021. THE CMAQ FUNDS HAVE BEEN TRANSFERRED TO REGION IV FOR TARCS PROJECT.THESE FUNDS ARE INCORPORATED INTO KENTUCKYS FY 2019-2022 STIP (10/11/2018) WITH ADMINISTRATIVE MODIFICATION 2018.006 (APRIL 9 2020) WHICH ADDED KIPDAS 2020-2025 TIP BY REFERENCE. THIS PROJECT (KIPDA ID #2668) IS LISTED ON PAGES 212-213 OF THAT TIP. BOTH DOCUMENTS ARE ATTACHED. PURPOSE OF AWARDTARCS PRIMARY PURPOSE FOR THIS PROJECT IS THE REPLACEMENT OF HIGH EMISSION BUSES. TARC BELIEVES THAT ZERO-EMISSION BUSES ARE THE KEY TO REDUCING MAINTENANCE COSTS AND BECOMING MORE SUSTAINABLE. A SECONDARY PURPOSE IS TO COMPARE THE OPERATING COSTS AND CHARACTERISTICS OF THESE EXTENDED RANGE BUSES WITH TARCS EXISTING FAST-CHARGE ELECTRIC BUSES. A PORTION OF THE FUNDS REQUESTED WILL PROVIDE THE EQUIVALENT OF ONE 50-60 KW DEPOT CHARGER FOR EACH BUS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMEDTARC WILL PURCHASE EIGHT (8) EXTENDED-RANGE FULL ELECTRIC BUSES AND EIGHT (8) DEPOT CHARGERS. THE DEPOT CHARGERS WILL BE LOCATED IN TARCS UNION STATION BUS STORAGE BUILDING WHERE CHARGING WILL PRIMARILY OCCUR OVERNIGHT.TARC HAS PARTNERED WITH CALSTART A NATIONAL NON-PROFIT AND LEADER IN CLEAN TRANSPORTATION FOR THEIR PROJECT MANAGEMENT ASSISTANCE AND A DETAILED FLEET ELECTRIFICATION PLAN. CALSTART WILL ASSIST TARC WITH PROJECT MANAGEMENT TASKS ASSOCIATED WITH BOTH VEHICLE (BUS) AND CHARGING INFRASTRUCTURE SPECIFICATIONS AND WITH DATA COLLECTION. THE COLLECTED DATA WILL IDENTIFY KEY VARIABLES TO ACCURATELY COMPARE COSTS AND BENEFITS OF TARCS DIESEL FLEET WITH ITS NEW EXTENDED RANGE BATTERY ELECTRIC BUSES. EXPECTED OUTCOMESTARC ESTIMATES THAT REPLACEMENT OF THE MODEL YEAR 2005 BUSES WITH ZERO EMISSION BATTERY ELECTRIC BUSES WILL RESULT IN REDUCTION IN UP TO 12000 POUNDS PER YEAR OF NOX AS MUCH AS THREE TONS OF CO PER YEAR AND HUNDREDS OF POUNDS OF PARTICULATE MATTER (PM 10 AND PM 2.5 PER YEAR.) TARC EXPECTS SERVICE TO IMPROVE THROUGH INCREASED RELIABILITY WHILE REDUCING THE ENERGY CONSUMPTION AND OPERATING EXPENSES OF TARCS FLEET. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES TARC WANTS TO ELECTRIFY ONE OF THREE ROUTES: 27 21 OR 29. THE AREA SERVED BY ROUTE 27 FOR EXAMPLE HAS BEEN IDENTIFIED AS 85% ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE AREA. THE POPULATION WITHIN MILE OF ROUTE 27 IS 63.6% NON-WHITE AND 28.9% LOW-INCOME. REDUCED EMISSIONS WILL IMPROVE THE AIR QUALITY AND THE RELIABLE TRANSPORTATION WILL CONNECT PEOPLE WITH JOBS EDUCATION AND HEALTHCARE.TARCS FFY 2019 CMAQ FLEXED FUNDS TOTAL $1955200 ($1564160 FEDERAL AND $391040 LOCAL MATCH). THE CMAQ AWARD WILL FUND THE FOLLOWING ACTIVITIES:1. PURCHASE OF TWO (2) EXTENDED RANGE FULL-ELECTRIC 40-FT BUSES $1845200 ($1476160 FEDERAL FUNDS AND $369040 LOCAL MATCH)2. PURCHASE OF TWO (2) DEPOT CHARGERS $110000 ($88000 FEDERAL FUNDS AND $22000 LOCAL MATCH)TARCS FFY 2021 SECTION 5339(C) LONO FUNDS TOTAL $4026658 ($3422659 FEDERAL FUNDS AND $603999 LOCAL MATCH)THE SECTION 5339(C) LONO AWARD WILL FUND THE FOLLOWING ACTIVITIES:3. PURCHASE OF SIX (6) EXTENDED RANGE FULL-ELECTRIC 40-FT BUSES $3231158 ($2746484 FEDERAL FUNDS AND $484674 LOCAL MATCH). THE REMAINING $1980000 WILL BE PROVIDED BY TARC SECTION 5339 FORMULA BUS AND BUS FACILITIES PROGRAM AWARD 1105-2022-4.4. PURCHASE OF SIX (6) DEPOT CHARGERS $600000 ($510000 FEDERAL FUNDS AND $90000 LOCAL MATCH)5. PROJECT MANAGEMENT 3RD PARTY $195500 ($166175 FEDERAL FUNDS AND $29325 LOCAL MATCH) TARC WILL REPLACE EIGHT (8) 40-FT DIESEL OR HYBRID BUSES THAT HAVE BEEN IN SERVICE SINCE 2009. (SEE ATTACHED EXCEL SPREADSHEET.) TARC WILL OWN OPERATE AND MAINTAIN THESE REPLACEMENT BUSES. THE NEW HEAVY-DUTY EXTENDED-RANGE BUSES WILL HAVE A MINIMUM EXPECTED USEFUL LIFE OF 12 YEARS OR 500000 MILES IN SERVICE. THE NEW ELECTRIC DEPOT CHARGERS ARE ESTIMATED TO HAVE THE SAME MINIMUM EXPECTED LIFE OF 12 YEARS.TARC WILL FOLLOW ALL 3RD PARTY PROCUREMENT POLICIES AS DEFINED IN C4220.1F (THIRD PARTY CONTRACTING GUIDANCE). TARC WILL ENSURE THAT AN INDEPENDENT COST ESTIMATE WILL BE PREPARED AND AVAILABLE ON FILE ALONG WITH THE CORRESPONDING COST/PRICE ANALYSIS FOR THE SCOPE OF THE PROJECT. TARC WILL ENSURE CONTRACTORS PROCURED WILL NOT BE ON THE FTA SUSPENSION AND DEBARMENT LIST. TARC WILL ENSURE THAT THE MANUFACTURERS OF ALL NEW BUSES ARE FTA CERTIFIED TVM SUPPLIERS. THE NEW BUSES WILL MEET ALL REQUISITE REGULATORY REQUIREMENTS INCLUDING THOSE ASSOCIATED WITH FEDERAL MOTOR VEHICLE SAFETY STANDARDS CLEAN AIR ACT (CAA) THE AMERICANS WITH DISABILITIES ACT OF 1990 AND THE BUY AMERICA ACT. TARC WILL MAINTAIN OR IMPROVE ACCESSIBILITY WHENEVER POSSIBLE IN KEEPING WITH THE ADA STANDARDS FOR TRANSPORTATION FACILITIES BASED ON THE U.S. ACCESS BOARDS ADA ACCESSIBILITY GUIDELINES.THIS APPLICATION DOES NOT INCLUDE FUNDS FOR RESEARCH AND/OR DEVELOPMENT ACTIVITIES. INDIRECT COSTS WILL NOT BE APPLIED TO THIS APPLICATION AND ITS SCOPE OF WORK. THESE GRANT ACTIVITIES ARE CATEGORICALLY EXCLUDED UNDER NEPA. TARC IS THE DESIGNATED RECIPIENT FOR THE LOUISVILLE METRO AREA.

APPLICATION PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THE FY 2022 LOW AND NO EMISSION BUS PROGRAM (5339(C)) PROVIDES FUNDING TO STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTAL ENTITIES FOR THE PURCHASE OR LEASE OF ZERO-EMISSION TRANSIT BUSES AS WELL AS ACQUISITION CONSTRUCTION AND LEASING OF REQUIRED SUPPORTING FACILITIES. LAWRENCE TRANSIT IS APPLYING FOR $3279655 TO FUND THE INCREMENTAL COST OF TWO (2) 40-FOOT BATTERY-ELECTRIC BUSES TWO (2) VMC OPTIMAL S1 LOW-FLOOR ELECTRIC CUTAWAY BUSES ONE (1) CHARGING DISPENSER (100% LOCAL) AND PROJECT MANAGEMENT SERVICES.; ACTIVITIES PERFORMED: LAWRENCE TRANSIT WILL PARTNER WITH THE CENTER FOR TRANSPORTATION AND THE ENVIRONMENT (CTE) PROTERRA CHARGE POINT INC. AND KU FACILITIES PLANNING DEVELOPMENT TO DEPLOY TWO (2) BATTERY-ELECTRIC BUSES SERVING THE CITY OF LAWRENCE KS IN DOUGLAS COUNTY KANSAS. PROTERRA IS A LEADER IN THE DESIGN AND MANUFACTURE OF ELECTRIC TRANSIT BUSES. CTE HAS A PROVEN TRACK RECORD OF PROJECT MANAGEMENT AND TECHNICAL SERVICES WITH THE DEPARTMENTS OF TRANSPORTATION (DOT) DEFENSE (DOD) AND ENERGY (DOE).; EXPECTED OUTCOMES: LAWRENCE TRANSIT AND THE UNIVERSITY OF KANSAS WORK TOGETHER TO PROVIDE SAFE CONVENIENT AFFORDABLE RELIABLE AND RESPONSIVE PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION SERVICES TO ENHANCE THE SOCIAL EDUCATIONAL ECONOMIC AND ENVIRONMENTAL WELL-BEING OF THE COMMUNITY. THIS ENCOMPASSES 20 FIXED ROUTES: 10 CITY ROUTES 2 COORDINATED ROUTES AND 8 UNIVERSITY ROUTES COVERING 31 SQUARE MILES WITHIN THE CITY LIMITS OF LAWRENCE. LAWRENCE TRANSIT SYSTEM ALSO PROVIDES T LIFT COMPLEMENTARY AMERICANS WITH DISABILITIES ACT PARATRANSIT SERVICES AND NIGHTTIME DEMAND RESPONSE SERVICE (NIGHT LINE).; INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: LAWRENCE TRANSIT A DIVISION OF THE CITY OF LAWRENCE KANSAS IS COMMITTED TO PROVIDING HIGH-QUALITY PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION SERVICES TO ALL CITIZENS AND VISITORS IN THE COMMUNITY AND THAT NO PERSON IS EXCLUDED FROM PARTICIPATION IN OR DENIED THE BENEFITS OF ITS SERVICES ON THE BASIS OF RACE COLOR OR NATIONAL ORIGIN AS PROVIDED BY TITLE VI OF THE CIVIL RIGHTS ACT OF 1964 AS AMENDED.; SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THE CITY OF LAWRENCE KS - LAWRENCE TRANSIT DOES NOT PASS THROUGH FUNDS TO ANY SUBRECIPIENTS.

ALLOWING WICHITA TRANSIT TO CONCENTRATE ON OUR OPERATIONS INSTEAD OF WORRYING ABOUT SYSTEM MAINTENANCE. AVAIL STRIVES TO FOLLOW INDUSTRY-STANDARD BEST PRACTICES UTILIZING FIREWALLS DMZ NETWORKS AND ISOLATION OF CUSTOMER NETWORKS. WICHITA TRANSIT A DEPARTMENT OF THE CITY OF WICHITA WAS AWARDED $14232816 IN FY2019 BUS AND BUS FACILITY COMPETITIVE FEDERAL FUNDS FOR A MULTIMODAL CENTER. THESE FUNDS ARE LISTED UNDER KANSAS UZA 200000 (2019.25.34.BC). THIS PROJECT WAS PROGRAMMED IN THE FY2021-2024 APPROVED TRANSPORTATION IMPROVEMENT PROGRAM (TIP ID#40-570 WHICH IS INCORPORATED BY REFERENCE IN THE KANSAS STIP. WE ARE APPLYING $800000 OF THE AWARD TO ENGINEERING DESIGN WITH A LOCAL MATCH OF $200000. THE CITY PORTION OF THE LOCAL MATCH WILL BE FINANCED USING THE CITY OF WICHITA/WICHITA TRANSITS CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT PROGRAM (CIP) FUNDS.THE CURRENT GRANT APPLICATION SCHEMATIC DRAWING INCLUDES AN ALLOCATION OF APPROXIMATELY 5000 SQ FT OF RETAIL SPACE. HOWEVER THE APPLICATION NARRATIVE DID NOT PLAN FOR NOR PROJECT ANY SPECIFIC JOINT DEVELOPMENT STAKEHOLDER. THE PROJECT SITE IS BOUNDED AND LIMITED BY STREETSON ALL FOUR SIDES AND PROVIDES NO ROOM FOR EXPANSION. THE CITYS PARAMOUNT CONCERN IS TO USE ALL AVAILABLE SPACE NECESSARY WITHIN THE SITE FOOTPRINT FOR CURRENT TRANSIT OPERATIONS AND FORESEEABLE EXPANSION. THE CITY WILL USE THE TRAFFIC PLANNING AND ENGINEERING EXPERTISE OF THE ARCHITECTURAL AND ENGINEERING DESIGN TEAM TO MAKE A FRESH EVALUATION OF SPACE NEEDS FOR THIS PURPOSE. UNTIL THAT PLANNING AND DESIGN DUE DILIGENCE IS COMPLETE THE CITY HAS NO PLANS FOR JOINT DEVELOPMENT. THE CITY DOES NOT WANT TO TAKE ON A JOINT DEVELOPMENT PARTICIPANT WHICH WOULD PRESENT SPACE AND DESIGN DEMANDS WHICH MIGHT CHALLENGE OPTIMAL DEVELOPMENT FOR TRANSIT ACTIVITIES. THIS PLANNING EXERCISE WILL INCLUDE INTERIOR AND BUS SLIP SPACE FOR GREYHOUND INTERCITY BUS SERVICE AND BEE-LINE INTERCITY BUS SERVICE PROVIDING LINKS TO TWO DIFFERENT AMTRAK LINES. THESE ENTITIES WILL PROVIDE NO DIRECT FUNDING FOR FACILITY CONSTRUCTION BUT WILL PAY RENT AT MANY MULTIPLES OF FMV FOR THE INTERIOR RETAIL SPACE USED TO ACCOUNT FOR THEIR INTERMITTENT USE OF BUS SLIP SPACE AND SIGNAGE RIGHTS. WHEN THE DESIGN DUE DILIGENCE EXERCISE IS COMPLETE AND TO THE EXTENT SPACE IS AVAILABLE FOR INCIDENTAL USE THE DESIGN TEAM WILL PROVIDE FOR JOINT DEVELOPMENT COMMERCIAL OPTIONS ON THE PROJECT SITE SUBJECT TO FTA APPROVAL. SUCH A JOINT DEVELOPMENT PARTNER WILL BE APPROACHED IN THE TYPICAL COMMERCIAL MANNER - NO DIRECT PARTICIPATION IN CONSTRUCTION COSTS BUT RENTAL PAYMENTS AND PROPORTIONAL UTILITY PAYMENTS COMMENSURATE WITH THE FMV OF THE SPACE UTILIZED.

APPLICATION PURPOSE: SUPER-STOPS 2.0 SEEKS TO IMPROVE TRANSIT SERVICES AND INCREASE FREQUENCY OF BUSES ON PRIMARY STREETS WITHIN INDIANAPOLIS CENTRAL BUSINESS DISTRICT LEADING TO IMPROVED SYSTEM-WIDE RELIABILITY. THE PROJECT WILL IMPROVE THE PASSENGER EXPERIENCE ALONG BUSY TRANSIT-SERVED STREETS BY INTRODUCING PASSENGER AMENITIES THAT ARE MORE IN LINE WITH WHAT IS OFFERED BY INDYGOS BUS RAPID TRANSIT SERVICES.; INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: ALL TRANSIT RIDERSHIP; SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: N/A

APPLICATION PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO SUPPORT THE DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION OF BUS STOP IMPROVEMENTS THROUGHOUT OUR COMMUNITY. THE IMPROVEMENTS BRING THESE BUS STOPS INTO FULL ADA COMPLIANCE AND PROVIDE VARIOUS LEVELS OF PASSENGER AMENITIES BASED ON RIDERSHIP AT THAT PARTICULAR STOP. HAVING FULLY ACCESSIBLE BUS STOPS ENHANCES TRANSPORTATION IN OUR COMMUNITY BY PROVIDING GREATER ACCESS TO EVERYONE USING OUR SYSTEM.; ACTIVITIES PERFORMED: FUNDS WILL BE USED TO DESIGN BUS STOPS TO BE COMPLIANT WITH ADA REQUIREMENTS. DESIGNS WILL BE BASED ON RIDERSHIP IN THE AREA TO ALLOW FOR ACCOMMODATIONS FOR CERTAIN PASSENGER AMENITIES AT EACH LOCATION SUCH AS BENCHES SOLAR POWER LIGHTS OR BUS SHELTERS. CONNECT TRANSITS DESIGN FIRM WILL COORDINATE WITH BOTH MUNICIPALITIES TO ENSURE BUS STOP IMPROVEMENT PROJECTS ALIGN WITH PLANNED SIDEWALK MAINTENANCE ACTIVITIES TO IMPROVE TO OVERALL ACCESSIBILITY OF OUR COMMUNITY.AFTER DESIGN THE FUNDING WILL ALSO SUPPORT THE CONSTRUCTION OF BUS STOPS. CONSTRUCTION ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE DEMOLITION OF EXISTING CONCRETE EXCAVATION OF OLD MATERIAL AND NECESSARY DIRT FORMING / POURING OF NEW CONCRETE AND REPAIR OF DISTURBED LANDSCAPING.; EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THIS FUNDING WILL HELP CONNECT TRANSIT ACHIEVE OUR GOAL OF IMPROVING ALL BUS STOPS THROUGHOUT OUR COMMUNITY TO BE SURE THEY HAVE PROPER ADA SPECIFICATIONS TO HELP IMPROVE THE OVERALL ACCESSIBILITY OF OUR SYSTEM. THE PRIMARY BENEFICIARY OF THIS PROJECT IS CUSTOMERS THAT MUST UTILIZE ANY TYPE OF MOBILITY DEVICE TO ACCESS OUR BUSES. HAVING FULLY ACCESSIBLE CONCRETE PADS THROUGHOUT OUR COMMUNITY WILL MAKE BOARDING AND ALIGHTING BUSES MUCH EASIER. IN ADDITION ALL PASSENGERS WILL BENEFIT FROM IMPROVED BUS STOPS SOME OF WHICH WILL INCLUDE ADDITIONAL AMENITIES SUCH AS BENCHES AND SHELTERS. PROPERTY OWNERS WILL ENJOY IMPROVED STOPS THAT INCLUDE TRASH RECEPTACLES TO HELP REDUCE LITTER AROUND THE STOPS. FINALLY THE CITY OF BLOOMINGTON TOWN OR NORMAL AND CONNECT TRANSIT WILL BENEFIT BY HAVING WIDER AND SAFER SIDEWALKS NEAR BUS STOPS WITH NO CRACKS THAT CAUSE TRIPPING HAZARDS.; INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: CONNECT TRANSITS PASSENGERS WILL BENEFIT FROM THIS PROJECT ESPECIALLY THOSE THAT ARE USING ANY TYPE OF MOBILITY DEVICE. MANY OF OUR BUS STOPS THROUGHOUT THE COMMUNITY ARE IN AREAS THAT DO NOT HAVE SIDEWALKS OR ANY OTHER INFRASTRUCTURE AND THEREFORE ARE NOT IDEAL LOCATIONS FOR BUS STOPS. IN ORDER TO SERVE THOSE AREAS WITH BUS ROUTES CONNECT TRANSIT HAS HAD TO PUT STOPS IN LOCATIONS THAT ARE NOT NECESSARILY EASY TO ACCESS. THE UPGRADED STOPS WILL PROVIDE A CONCRETE CONNECTION TO THE NEAREST SIDEWALK OR HARD SURFACE WITH ADA COMPLIANT DESIGNS AND CONSIDERATIONS. ALL PASSENGERS WILL BENEFIT FROM EASIER ACCESS SAFER SIDEWALKS AND BETTER BUS STOPS.; SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NONE

APPLICATION PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO SUPPORT THE DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION OF A TRANSIT CENTER IN DOWNTOWN BLOOMINGTON ILLINOIS. CURRENTLY NO STAND-ALONE TRANSIT FACILITY IS LOCATED WITHIN DOWNTOWN BLOOMINGTON WHICH IS ONE OF THE CENTRAL MOBILITY HUBS IN THE CONNECT TRANSIT SERVICE AREA. THIS AREA HANDLES AS MANY AS 2000 RIDERS PER DAY. ON-STREET TRANSFER POINTS ARE LOCATED ON THE SOUTH SIDES OF 100 AND 200 WEST FRONT STREETS APPROXIMATELY TWO BLOCKS FROM THE PROPOSED LOCATION. HOWEVER THESE TWO LOCATIONS CURRENTLY ONLY INCLUDE ONE BUS STOP SHELTER AND BENCH AT EACH LOCATION WHICH RAISES SAFETY AND ACCESSIBILITY CONCERNS.WHILE FREQUENT RIDERS ARE ACCUSTOMED WITH HOW TO TRANSFER BUSES ALONG FRONT STREET THE REQUIREMENT TO CROSS FRONT STREET TO MAKE A TRANSFER CAN BE CONFUSING AND CAN CREATE SAFETY CONCERNS FOR THOSE WHO ARE UNFAMILIAR WITH THE AREA OR ARE INFREQUENT OR NEW RIDERS. THE TRANSFER POINTS CAN BE COMPLICATED WITH HEAVY VEHICULAR MOVEMENTS ON WEST FRONT STREET AND A STEADY STREAM OF BUSES ENTERING AND EXITING THE AREA. IN ADDITION THE LIMITED AVAILABILITY OF BUS SHELTERS AND BENCHES PARTICULARLY DURING ADVERSE WEATHER CONDITIONS PROVIDES INCREASED SAFETY AND QUALITY OF RIDERSHIP CONCERNS DURING RIDER TRANSFER AND WAITING PERIODS.THE LACK OF A STAND-ALONE TRANSIT FACILITY ALSO AFFECTS THE RELIABILITY AND EFFICIENCY OF TRANSIT OPERATIONS. BECAUSE OF THE LACK OF SPACE AT THE EXISTING TRANSFER POINTS ONLY SEVEN BUSES CAN CONVERGE AT ONE TIME. THIS LIMITS BUS ROUTE SCHEDULING PARTICULARLY DURING PEAK PERIODS WHEN DEMAND IS HIGHEST. THIS LACK OF SPACE PREVENTS CONNECT TRANSIT FROM OPERATING EFFICIENTLY AND CONVENIENTLY BY NOT ALLOWING CUSTOMERS TO TRANSFER TO ANOTHER BUS SEAMLESSLY. THIS LACK OF SPACE ALSO LIMITS THE TRANSIT SERVICES ABILITY TO EXPAND ROUTE CAPABILITIES IN THE FUTURE.; ACTIVITIES PERFORMED: FUNDS WILL BE USED TO DESIGN DEMOLISH AND CONSTRUCT THE TRANSIT RELATED COMPONENTS OF THE TRANSIT CENTER. ADDITIONAL ACTIVITIES THAT ARE REQUIRED FOR THIS PROJECT WILL INCLUDE CONSTRUCTION MANAGEMENT AND RELOCATION OF A US POST OFFICE WHICH IS LOCATED IN THE CURRENT FACILITY.; EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE NEW FACILITY WILL PROMOTE AND ENHANCE CONNECT TRANSITS MISSION OF PROVIDING SAFE RELIABLE AND SUSTAINABLE TRANSPORTATION THROUGHOUT THE BLOOMINGTON-NORMAL COMMUNITY.; INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: BECAUSE THIS PROJECT INCLUDES THE CONSTRUCTION OF A NEW TRANSIT CENTER AND BUS TRANSFER FACILITY IT IS INTENDED TO PRIMARILY RESULT IN PUBLIC TRANSIT BENEFITS TO THE LOCAL PUBLIC TRANSIT USERS AND THE LOCAL COMMUNITY. BENEFITS WOULD INCLUDE ENHANCING CONNECT TRANSIT SERVICES BY IMPROVING SAFETY ACCESS RELIABILITY AND THE OVERALL EXPERIENCE FOR PASSENGERS. IN ADDITION IT WOULD IMPROVE TRAFFIC CONDITIONS BY REMOVING THE EXISTING BUS TRANSFER POINTS FROM A KEY THOROUGHFARE. WITH A NEW TRANSIT CENTER LEASABLE SPACES STREETSCAPING IMPROVEMENTS AND OTHER ENHANCEMENTS THIS COULD LEAD TO FURTHER ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT AND REVITALIZATION OF THE LOCAL NEIGHBORHOOD SURROUNDING THE SITE.CONNECT TRANSIT EMPLOYEES ARE ALSO A BENEFICIARY OF THIS PROJECT BY HAVING A SAFER AND CLEANER LOCATION TO DWELL. THE CURRENT LOCATION HAS NO PUBLIC RESTROOM FACILITIES OR AREAS DESIGNED FOR DRIVERS LAYOVER AT THE TRANSFER FACILITY. THE NEW DESIGN WILL HAVE RESTROOMS AND REFRESHMENT AREAS FOR BUS OPERATORS WHILE ALSO PROVIDING COVER DURING PERIODS OF SNOW OR RAIN. IN ADDITION HAVING A DEDICATED FACILITY OFF-STREET WILL ENHANCE SAFETY OF BUS OPERATORS BY ALLOWING THEM TO EXIT THEIR VEHICLES WITHOUT INTERACTING WITH TRAFFIC IN THE AREA.THE CITY OF BLOOMINGTON WILL BENEFIT BY WORKING WITH CONNECT TRANSIT ON THIS PROJECT BY BUILDING A NEW PARKING AND TRANSIT FACILITY THAT BECOMES THE MOBILITY HUB OF DOWNTOWN BLOOMINGTON ALLOWING PUBLIC TRANSIT RIDERS AND PERSONAL AUTOMOBILE USERS TO ACCESS THE OPPORTUNITIES FOR EMPLOYMENT RECREATION SHOPPING AND DINING. IN ADDITION THAT CITY WILL LIKELY EXPERIENCE COST SAVINGS BY REDUCED MAINTENANCE AND REPAIR COSTS TO THE EXISTING FACILITY THAT IS IN NEED OF SIGNIFICANT IMPROVEMENT.; SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NONE

THIS TRANSIT SERVICE OFFERS A HIGHLY FLEXIBLE ROUTING AND/OR HIGHLY FLEXIBLE SCHEDULING OF MINIBUS VEHICLES SHARED WITH OTHER PASSENGERS.; ACTIVITIES PERFORMED: THIS APPLICATION WILL UTILIZE FUNDING FOR THE PURCHASE OF THREE VEHICLES. APPLICATION PURPOSE: GREATER PEORIA MASS TRANSIT DISTRICT (GPMTD) WILL BE REPLACING THE GPMTD EXISTING ADMINISTRATION BUILDING ROOF AND PURCHASING NEW DIESEL BUSES TO REPLACE EXISTING DIESEL BUSES WHICH HAVE SURPASSED THEIR USEFUL LIFE.; ACTIVITIES PERFORMED: THE GPMTD EXISTING ADMINISTRATION BUILDING ROOF (ORIGINAL ROOF IS 30 YEAR OLD) WILL HAVE THE FOLLOWING ACTIVITIES PERFORMED AS DESIGNED AND RECOMMENDED BY THE GPMTD AE SERVICE PROVIDER:- FULL ROOF TEAR-OFF; - TEMPORARY ROOFING;- BASE FLASHING REMOVAL;- DISPOSAL OF ALL OLD ROOFING MATERIALS;- EXISTING ROOF DRAINS AND ROOF DRAINAGE FIXED REMOVED OR REALIGNED FOR NEW ROOF INSTALLATION;- EXISTING ROOF DECK AND BASE FLASHING ANALYZED FOR CONDITION AND FIXED PRIOR TO NEW ROOF INSTALLATION;- ROOF EQUIPMENT PROTECTED (HVAC ETC.) AND REWORKED FOR NEW ROOF INSTALLATION;- ADHERED POLYVINYL CHLORIDE (PVC) ROOFING SYSTEM; - WARRANTIES AND CERTIFICATIONS OF WARRANTIES.THE GPMTD WILL PROCURE DIESEL BUSES TO REPLACE CURRENT DIESEL BUSES THAT HAVE SURPASSED THEIR USEFUL LIFE. THE FUNDING UNDER THIS GRANT WILL BE COMBINED WITH OTHER EXISTING AND FUTURE GPMTD GRANTS TO REPLACE ELIGIBLE BUSES AS THE FLEET TURNS OVER IN THE NEXT TWO TO THREE YEARS. APPROXIMATELY 46 BUSES WILL BE REPLACED DURING THE NEXT SEVERAL YEARS. ADDITIONAL DETAILS RELATED TO THE REPLACEMENT OF THE GPMTD ADMINISTRATION BUILDING ROOF AND PURCHASE OF NEW DIESEL BUSES AS WELL AS MAJOR PROJECT TIMELINES ARE INCLUDED IN THE APPLICATION OF THIS GRANT; EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE GPMTD ADMINISTRATION BUILDING ROOF REPLACEMENT WILL PROTECT THE BUILDING FROM CURRENT LEAKS THAT ARE OCCURRING AND CAN NO LONGER BE PATCHED DUE TO THE AGE OF THE EXISTING ROOF. THE COMPLETE REPLACEMENT WILL PROTECT THE ADMINISTRATION BUILDING AND A PROVIDE BETTER DRAINAGE SYSTEM. THE ACQUISITION OF NEW DIESEL BUSES WILL PROVIDE A MORE RELIABLE COMFORTABLE TRANSPORTATION MODE FOR RIDERS AND EMPLOYEES WITH UPDATE TECHNOLOGY AND COMFORTS.; INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THE GPMTD EMPLOYEES RIDERS AND COMMUNITY WILL BENEFIT FROM THE REPLACEMENT OF THE GPTMD ADMINISTRATION BUILDING ROOF AND THE PURCHASE OF NEW DIESEL BUSES AS INDICATED IN THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES SECTION.; SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NONE

APPLICATION PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO PROVIDE CONTINUED ACCESS TO PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION WITH A FLEET THAT PRODUCES LOWER AMOUNTS OF CARBON DIOXIDE EMISSIONS; ACTIVITIES PERFORMED: SMTD ACTIVITIES INCLUDE REPLACING EIGHT EXISTING DIESEL BUSES THAT EXCEED THEIR MINIMUM USEFUL LIFE WITH LOWER EMISSION BUSES BY REPLACING EIGHT DIESEL BUSES WITH FOUR CNG BUSES AND 4 DIESEL HYBRID BUSES.; EXPECTED OUTCOMES: WITH THIS AWARD SMTD EXPECTS TO REDUCE THE DIESEL FLEET FROM 57% TO 43% AND WILL INCREASE THE CNG FLEET FROM 37% TO 43% WITH AN EXPECTED OVERALL FLEET ONCE THIS PROJECT IS COMPLETED TO 43% DIESEL 43% CNG AND 13% DIESEL HYBRID.; INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE LOCAL CITIZENS WHO WILL BENEFIT FROM REDUCED EMISSIONS AND FROM THE INCREASED RELIABILITY OF TRANSPORTATION SERVICE WITH NEWER VEHICLES. THE BENEFITS OF THIS AWARD ALSO INCLUDE REDUCING ENERGY CONSUMPTION REDUCING HARMFUL EMISSIONS REDUCING DIRECT CARBON EMISSIONS MAINTAINING A FLEET OF GOOD REPAIR AND MEETING TAM TARGETS.; SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES FOR THIS AWARD.

PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD:GREATER PEORIA MASS TRANSIT DISTRICT (GPMTD) WILL USE THE FULL APPORTIONMENT OF THE COMPETITIVELY AWARDED FY20 SECTION 5339(B) BUS AND BUS FACILITIES INFRASTRUCTURE INVESTMENT PROGRAM FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $10000000 TOWARDS THE CONSTRUCTION AND RENOVATION OF THE GPMTD MAINTENANCE OPERATIONS AND ADMINISTRATION COMPLEX WHICH INCLUDES THE CONSTRUCTION OF NEW MAINTENANCE OPERATIONS AND ADMINISTRATION COMPLEX AS WELL AS THE RENOVATION OF THE CURRENT MAINTENANCE OPERATIONS AND ADMINISTRATION BUILDINGS. GPMTD WILL USE PART OF THE ILLINOIS DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION GRANT (GRANT#CAP-14-1027-ILL) IN THE AMOUNT OF $2500000 AS THE LOCAL MATCH FOR THE REFERENCED CAPITAL PROJECT UNDER THIS GRANT APPLICATION. THE GPMTD MAINTENANCE OPERATIONS AND ADMINISTRATION COMPLEX WILL BE COMPLETED IN THREE (3) PHASES (B C AND D) WITH AN OPTION FOR A FOURTH (4TH) PHASE. THE DESIGN FOR PHASES B C AND D ARE NEAR 100% COMPLETE PENDING COSMETIC CHANGES THAT DO NOT IMPACT THE NEW STRUCTURE. THE GPMTD MAINTENANCE OPERATIONS AND ADMINISTRATION COMPLEX PROJECT STARTED UNDER GRANT IL-2021-020-00 (A COMPETITIVE FY17 SECTION 5339 (B) BUS AND BUS FACILITIES INFRASTRUCTURE INVESTMENT PROGRAM FUNDING) FOR THE PHASE A PROJECT WHICH INCLUDES CONSTRUCTION OF A REAR BUILDING (PAINT AND BODY SHOP) ON THE CURRENT GPMTD PROPERTY. THE GPMTD MAINTENANCE OPERATIONS AND ADMINISTRATION COMPLEX IS A MULTI-YEAR PROJECT USING FTA AWARDS AND APPORTIONMENTS AN ILLINOIS STATE CAPITAL GRANT AND AWARDED ILLINOIS (FY20 AND FY21) REBUILD FUNDING.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:PHASES B C AND D INCLUDES THE EXCAVATION AND CONSTRUCTION OF THE MAINTENANCE ADMINISTRATION AND OPERATIONS COMPLEX AS WELL AS THE RENOVATION OF THE CURRENT MAINTENANCE OPERATIONS AND ADMINISTRATION BUILDINGS LOCATED WITHIN THE CONFINES OF THE CURRENT GPMTD PROPERTY. THE MAINTENANCE ADMINISTRATION AND OPERATIONS COMPLEX INCLUDES SUCH DETAILS AS: SITE PREPARATION DEMOLITION AND IMPROVEMENTS EXCAVATION FOUNDATION AND SUBSTRUCTURE CONSTRUCTION SUPERSTRUCTURE INCLUDING FLOOR AND ROOF CONSTRUCTION EXTERIOR WALLS DOORS AND WINDOWS CONSTRUCTION INTERIOR DOORS FRAMES WALLS FLOORS BASE CEILING AND MISCELLANEOUS SPECIALTY FINISHES CONSTRUCTION PLUMBING MECHANICAL GAS PIPING HVAC DUCTWORK AND RELATED FIXTURES FIRE PROTECTION AND ELECTRICAL SITE UTILITIES STORM DRAIN GUTTER SYSTEM OTHER RELATED WORK TO COMPLETE THE PROJECT SUCH AS PERMITS MOISTURE MITIGATION ETC.ADDITIONAL DETAILS RELATED TO THE CONSTRUCTION AND RENOVATION DESIGN OF THE COMPLEX AS WELL AS MAJOR PROJECT TIMELINES ARE ATTACHED IN THE APPLICATION DOCUMENTS OF THIS GRANT.EXPECTED OUTCOME:THE RESULT OF CONSTRUCTION AND RENOVATION OF THE GPMTD MAINTENANCE OPERATIONS AND ADMINISTRATION COMPLEX WILL PROVIDE A NEW AND RENOVATED MAINTENANCE OPERATIONS AND ADMINISTRATION COMPLEX FOR THE TRI-COUNTY AREA AND GPMTD EMPLOYEES. THE COMPLEX WILL ALLOW THE GPMTD OPERATE MORE EFFICIENTLY WITH RESPECT TO MAINTENANCE BEING LOCATED IN ONE BUILDING ALLOWING CURRENT TECHNOLOGY TO BE INCORPORATED INTO THE COMPLEX AND SAFER WORKING ENVIRONMENT FOR EMPLOYEE WORK SPACES AND BUS STORAGE AREAS. THE NEW AND RENOVATED STRUCTURES WILL PROVIDE SAFER VEHICLE MOVEMENTS WITHOUT REQUIRING BUSES TO BACK-UP AND WILL ALLOW SEPARATION OF PERSONNEL AND BUS MOVEMENTS ON SITE. A NEW COMPLEX CONSTRUCTION AND RENOVATION ALLOWS OPPORTUNITY TO INCORPORATE THE LATEST BUILDING TECHNOLOGY TO INCLUDE SUSTAINABLE MEASURES LIKE ON-SITE RENEWABLE SOLAR POWER. GENERATING ADDITIONAL ENERGY WILL LOWER THE LIFE CYCLE COST OF FLEET OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES:A NEW COMPLEX AND RENOVATION OF THE EXISTING MAINTENANCE FACILITIES WILL SUPPORT PROGRESS IN TECHNOLOGY AND FLEET FLEXIBILITY FOR EFFICIENT AND EFFECTIVE SERVICE POTENTIALLY ENTICING FUTURE INVESTMENT THROUGH USE OF OPPORTUNITY FUNDS. THE GPMTD EMPLOYEES RIDERS AND COMMUNITY WILL BENEFIT FROM THE COMPLEX CONSTRUCTION AND RENOVATION AS INDICATED IN THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES SECTION.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES OR PROVIDE THE INFORMATION IF THERE ARE SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES.DOCUMENTS ATTACHED INCLUDE THE FTA/FHWA STIP APPROVAL LETTER OF 04/29/2021 NEPA AND SECTION 106 ORIGINAL APPROVAL AND RE-CERTIFICATION LETTERS TIP TABLE REFERENCING THIS PROJECT AND NOTICE OF AWARD.

THIS APPLICATION IS REQUESTING A TOTAL OF $1950000 IN LAPSING FTA FY2018 5339(B)FUNDS. THE AWARD WILL FUND TWO (2) PROJECTS INCLUDING BUS REPLACEMENTS AND A FACILITY PROJECT IN ILLINOIS DOWNSTATE REGION.THE PROJECTS ARE IN THE CITY OF GALESBURG (P1) AND THE CITY OF QUINCY (P3). CITY OF GALESBURG AND CITY OF QUINCY WERE ORIGINALLY SELECTED FOR FY2018 5339(B) DISCRETIONARY FUNDS TOTALING $2285000 IN FEDERAL FUNDS. A THIRD PROJECT FOR THE CITY OF MACOMB WAS INITIALLY SELECTED BUT WAS UNABLE TO MEET THE PLANNING REQUIREMENTS UNDER THIS PROGRAM. TOLL DEVELOPMENT CREDITS TOTALING THE EQUIVALENT OF $390000 WILL MATCH PROJECTS FOR CITY OF GALESBURG AND CITY OF QUINCY. THE DISCRETIONARY FUNDS WERE OFFICIALLY SELECTED ON 9/25/2018. THESE PROJECTS WILL BE ADMINISTERED JOINTLY BY THE ILLINOIS DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION (IDOT) AND THE LOCAL PROVIDER/AUTHORITY OF EACH PROJECT. THE QUINCY PROJECT IS ALSO FUNDED UNDER TWO OTHER FTA AWARDS SPECIFICALLY IL-04-0064-00 AND IL-04-0065-00. UNDER IL-04-0064-00 FEDERAL 5309 FUNDS IN THE AMOUNT OF $140000 ARE BEING USED TO SUPPORT THE BUS WASH IMPROVEMENT. ADDITIONALLY UNDER IL-04-0065-00 TWO ALIS IN THE AMOUNTS OF $872000 AND $96000 IN FEDERAL 5309 FUNDS WILL BE USED TO HELP COVER OTHER FACILITY IMPROVEMENTS. PROJECTS HAVE BEEN FULLY VETTED VIA IDOT INTERNAL PROJECT CONTROL PROCESSES AND WOULD BE READY TO COMMENCE IMMEDIATELY UPON AWARD OF FEDERAL GRANT FUNDS.ADDITIONAL DOCUMENTS ATTACHED TO THIS APPLICATION ARE AS FOLLOWS: GENERAL APPLICATION (DESCRIPTION; FILE NAME) - ORIGINAL 2018 APPLICATION; BUS-SUPPLEMENTAL-FORM-FY-2018_8-6-18.PDF- TIER II GROUP TAM PLAN; GROUP TAM PLAN_TIER II AGENCIES_V1.6.PDF- TDC COMMITMENT MEMO FOR THE 2018 PROJECTS CITY OF QUINCY MACOMB AND GALESBURG; IDOT TDC COMMITMENT MEMO.PDF- LIST OF ALL ADDITIONAL DOCUMENTS WITHIN THE APPLICATION; ADDITIONAL DOCUMENT LIST.PDFCITY OF GALESBURG (P1)- STATE TRANSIT ASSET MANAGEMENT PLAN (TAM); GROUP TAM PLAN_TIER II AGENCIES_V1.6.PDF- TDC COMMITMENT MEMO FOR THE 2018 PROJECTS; CITY OF QUINCY MACOMB AND GALESBURG; IDOT TDC COMMITMENT MEMO.PDF- PROOF OF PUBLIC NOTICE AND HEARING; GALESBURG APPLICATION WITH PUBLIC NOTICE P19-21.PDFCITY OF QUINCY (P3)- NEPA/SHPO DETERMINATION; 2021-03-01_IDOT QUINCY FTA DETERMINATION OF EFFECTS - SHPO CONCURRENCE REQUEST (002).PDF- DNR LETTER;1900 SEMINARY ROAD.PDF- LOCATION FACILITY INFORMATION; IDOT QUINCY ATTACHMENTS.PDF- TDC COMMITMENT MEMO FOR THE 2018 PROJECTS - CITY OF QUINCY MACOMB AND GALESBURG; IDOT TDC COMMITMENT MEMO.PDF- PROOF OF PUBLIC NOTICE AND HEARING; QUINCY 5339B APPLICATION PUBLIC HEARING-06-12-19 DOCS.PDFDISCRETIONARY ID: D2018BUSC167

**THIS GRANT INCLUDES LAPSING FUNDS**THIS GRANT WILL FUND THE PURCHASE OF THREE (3) 35-FOOT GILLIG BATTERY ELECTRIC BUSES AND ASSOCIATED CHARGING EQUIPMENT FOR ROCKFORD MASS TRANSIT DISTRICT (ROCKFORD MTD) AS SOLICITED AND APPROVED VIA IDOTS 2021 REBUILD ILLINOIS CALL FOR PROJECTS.THE TOTAL PROJECT COST IS $2659703. SPECIFICALLY RECIPIENT MUST ENSURE AS A CONDITION OF BEING AUTHORIZED TO BID OR PROPOSE ON FTA-ASSISTED TRANSIT VEHICLE PROCUREMENTS THAT EACH TRANSIT VEHICLE MANUFACTURER CERTIFIED THAT IT COMPLIED WITH DOT REQUIREMENTS FOR SUBMITTING A DBE PROGRAM AND GOAL TO FTA PRIOR TO BIDDING. RECIPIENT IS ALSO REQUIRED TO SUBMIT THE NAME OF THE SUCCESSFUL BIDDER AND THE TOTAL DOLLAR VALUE OF THE CONTRACT WITHIN 30 DAYS OF MAKING AN FTA- ASSISTED TRANSIT VEHICLE AWARD USING THE REQUIRED FTA REPORTING TOOL. RECIPIENT UNDERSTANDS THAT FAILURE TO COMPLY WITH THESE REQUIREMENTS MAY RESULT IN FORMAL ENFORCEMENT ACTION OR APPROPRIATE SANCTION AS DETERMINED BY FTA INCLUDING REIMBURSEMENT OF FTA FUNDS USED FOR THE VEHICLE PROCUREMENT.
